{{Coord|43|44|4.74|N|7|25|16.8|E|scale:1563_type:landmark_region:MC|display=title}} {{Infobox Grand Prix race report |Type = F1 |Country = Monaco |Grand Prix = Monaco |Official name = XIV Grand Prix Automobile de Monaco |Image = Circuit de Monaco 1950.png |Date = 13 May |Year = 1956 |Location = [[Circuit de Monaco]] |Course = Street Circuit |Course_mi = 1.954 |Course_km = 3.145 |Distance_laps = 100 |Distance_mi = 195.421 |Distance_km = 314.500 |Weather = Warm, dry, sunny |Pole_Driver = [[Juan Manuel Fangio]] |Pole_Team = [[Scuderia Ferrari|Ferrari]] |Pole_Time = 1:44.0 |Pole_Country = Argentina |Fast_Driver = [[Juan Manuel Fangio]] |Fast_Team = [[Scuderia Ferrari|Ferrari]] |Fast_Time = 1:44.4 |Fast_Lap = |Fast_Country = Argentina |First_Driver = [[Stirling Moss]] |First_Team = [[Maserati in motorsport|Maserati]] |First_Country = United Kingdom |Second_Driver = [[Peter Collins (racing driver)|Peter Collins]]
{{flagicon|Argentina}} [[Juan Manuel Fangio]] |Second_Team = [[Scuderia Ferrari|Ferrari]] |Second_Country= United Kingdom |Third_Driver = [[Jean Behra]] |Third_Team = [[Maserati in motorsport|Maserati]] |Third_Country = France |Lapchart = {{F1Laps1956|MON}} }} The '''1956 Monaco Grand Prix''' was a [[Formula One]] [[motor race]] held on 13 May 1956 at [[Circuit de Monaco|Monaco]]. It was race 2 of 8 in the [[1956 World Championship of Drivers]]. The Owen's B.R.M. made their first appearance but after qualifying both cars were withdrawn due to engine valve problems. The other two non-starters were also teammates: the too slow Scarlatti and Chiron due to his engine blowing up in practice. Moss, starting from the middle of the front row, took the lead at Gasworks on the first lap and led every lap. Fangio was not having a good day. He hit the straw bales on lap 2, causing Schell and Musso to retire when trying to avoid him, and on lap 32 he hit the harbour wall, bending a rear wheel. He turned the car over to Castellotti after the pit stop to fix the wheel. On lap 54 while second, Collins came in the pit and turned his car over to Fangio. He resumed in third and passed Behra for second on lap 70 but he was 47 seconds behind Moss. On lap 86 Perdisa's brakes locked when being lapped by Moss, the resulting contact caused Moss's bonnet to lift allowing Fangio to close the gap by two seconds each lap but Moss won with a 6-second cushion. == Classification == {| class="wikitable" style="font-size: 95%;" |- ! {{Year in Albania|2004}}
The following lists events that happened during '''[[2004]] in [[Albania|Republic of Albania]]'''.
== Incumbents == * [[President of Albania|President]]: [[Alfred Moisiu]] * [[Prime Minister of Albania|Prime Minister]]: [[Fatos Nano]]
== Events ==
=== February === * Opposition stages angry demonstration in Tirana to demand Mr Nano's resignation and protest against government failure to improve living standards.<ref name="bbc">[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/country_profiles/1004984.stm Albania timeline] BBC, A chronology of key events: 2004, news.bbc.co.uk</ref>
=== May === [[File:Anjeza Shahini.jpg|157px|thumb|right|[[Anjeza Shahini]] performing "The Image of You" at the semi-final.]] * In its first appearance in the competition, Albania is represented at the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2004]] by [[Anjeza Shahini]], who places 7th with the song "[[The Image of You]]".
=== July === * July 17: [[Susan of Albania]], wife of the pretender [[Leka, Crown Prince of Albania (born 1939)|Leka, Crown Prince of Albania]], dies of lung cancer in [[Tirana]]. <ref>https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/1467530/Queen-Susan-of-the-Albanians.html Obituary in ''Daily Telegraph''</ref>
=== September === * September 4: The political party [[Socialist Movement for Integration]] is formed by former prime minister [[Ilir Meta]].<ref>https://www.broadleft.org/al.htm Listing of leftist parties in Albania at Broadleft</ref>
=== December === * [[Edi Rama]], Mayor of [[Tirana]] elected World Mayor 2004.<ref>[http://www.citymayors.com/mayor2004/edirama_2004.html "City Mayors: Edi Rama - World Mayor 2004"], 6 tetor 2015</ref>
==See also== * [[2004 in Albanian television]]
== References == {{Reflist}}

revision.text:
{{Unreferenced|date=December 2009}}
The '''Ahoko''' is a traditional [[percussion instrument]] originating from the central part of [[Ivory Coast]] (Côte d'Ivoire) in [[Africa]].
The ahoko is a wooden rod with [[Nut (fruit)|nutshells]], each containing loose seeds, tied to strings which are then tightly wound around the end of the rod. The percussive sound can range from quiet to very loud.
In the [[Hornbostel–Sachs]] system it is categorised as 112.13 as a [[vessel rattle]], a type of [[indirectly struck idiophone]].
==See also== * [[Music of Africa]]
==External links== * https://web.archive.org/web/20100706201440/http://www.experiencefestival.com/a/List_of_musical_instruments_-_Percussion_instruments/id/1689127 lists the ''ahoko'' as an ''other percussion instrument'', i.e. not a drum. * http://www.hellotrade.com/african-treasures-com/juju-seed-rattle.html ''Juju Seed Rattle. Description: Also called Ahoko. Nutshells are attached at the end of a wooden handle to make a full resonant rattle sound. Effects range from a very loud tone when shaken strongly, to a quiet rattle when the handle is barely turned.''
[[Category:Struck idiophones]] [[Category:Ivorian musical instruments]] [[Category:Hand percussion]] [[Category:African percussion instruments]] [[Category:Unpitched percussion]]
{{Côted'Ivoire-stub}} {{Percussion-instrument-stub}}

[[Image:Carolans.jpg|thumb|right|Carolans Irish Cream]] '''Carolans Irish Cream''' (the registered trade mark omits the [[Apostrophe (punctuation)|apostrophe]]) is a [[liqueur]] made from a mixture of [[cream]], Irish [[Distilled beverage|spirits]], Irish [[whiskey]] and [[honey]].{{cite web|title=Carolans Irish Cream|url=http://www.carolans.ie/int/en/product/characteristics/|website=carolans.ie|publisher=Carolans|accessdate=20 December 2014}} Carolans was developed in 1978 and first sold in the UK in July 1979. It has a declared [[alcohol (drug)|alcohol]] content of 17% or 14.5% [[alcohol by volume]] (ABV). The liqueur is made in [[Clonmel]], [[County Tipperary]], in the [[Republic of Ireland]]. The brand is owned by [[Gruppo Campari]] and was previously owned by [[William Grant & Sons|William Grant]] and [[C&C Group]].http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/breaking/2010/0916/breaking15.html '''Commonly used description:'''
"Deep milky brown hue. Forward, spirity, whiskey-accented lactic flavors. A rich, milky attack leads to a moderately full-bodied palate with a touch of sweetness."http://wineflair.net/products/liqueurs/liqueur_products/cream_carolans.htm{{dead link|date=November 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}
==See also== *[[Irish cream]] ==External links== * [http://www.carolans.ie Official website] ==References== [[Category:Irish brands]] [[Category:Irish liqueurs]] [[Category:County Tipperary]] [[Category:Cream liqueurs]] [[Category:Campari Group]] [[Category:Products introduced in 1978]] {{Ireland-stub}} {{distilled-drink-stub}}

{{Infobox scientist | name = Christina Riesselman | image = Christina Riesselman.jpg | image_size = 240px | caption = Christina Riesselman in [[Moubray Bay]] | birth_name = | nationality = United States | fields = [[Paleoceanography]] | workplaces = [[University of Otago]] | alma_mater = BSc [[University of Nebraska-Lincoln|University Nebraska-Lincoln]]
PhD [[Stanford University]] | awards = [[L'Oréal#Community involvement and awards|L’Oréal]]-[[UNESCO#Official list of UNESCO prizes|UNESCO Fellowship]] For Women in Science (2015) | website = [http://www.otago.ac.nz/geology/staff/academic/christina-riesselman.html Riesselman at University of Otago] }} '''Christina Riesselman''' is an American [[Paleoceanography|paleoceanographer]] whose research focus is on [[Southern Ocean]] response to [[Climate change|changing climate]].{{Cite web|url=http://women.govt.nz/inspiring-women/christina-riesselman|title=Christina Riesselman|website=women.govt.nz|publisher=NZ Ministry for Women|access-date=2016-06-05}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.forwomeninscience.com.au/news/dr-christina-riesselman-geologist-university-of-otago-dunedin|title=Dr Christina Riesselman, geologist|date=2015|website=www.forwomeninscience.com.au|publisher=University of Otago|access-date=2016-06-06}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.sciencealert.com/here-are-four-of-the-most-exciting-women-in-science-right-now|title=Here are four of the most exciting women in science right now|last=Crew|first=Bec|website=ScienceAlert|access-date=2016-06-06}} ==Early life and education== After completing her bachelor's degree at the [[University of Nebraska–Lincoln|University of Nebraska-Lincoln]] in Geology and English in 2001, Riesselman spent time at the Joint Oceanographic Institution in Washington DC, then moved to [[Stanford University|Stanford]] for her PhD which was completed in 2011. ==Career == Following postdoctoral work as a Research Scientist with the [[United States Geological Survey|US Geological Survey]], she moved to the [[University of Otago]], New Zealand in 2013.{{Cite web|url=http://www.odt.co.nz/campus/university-otago/355196/complicated-path-women-science-grant|title='Complicated path' to women in science grant|date=2015|website=www.odt.co.nz|publisher=Otago Daily Times Online News|access-date=2016-06-05}} Riesselman uses [[diatom]] micropaleontology and stable isotope geochemistry in marine sediments to examine the evolution of the Antarctic cryosphere through the [[Cenozoic]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.exploratorium.edu/tv/index.php?project=9&program=560|title=Christina Riesselman Explains Her work|date=2007|website=www.exploratorium.edu|access-date=2016-06-06}}{{Cite journal|last=R.|first=Riesselman, Christina|last2=B.|first2=Dunbar, Robert|date=2012-01-01|title=Diatom Evidence for the Onset of Pliocene Cooling from AND-1B, McMurdo Sound, Antarctica|url=http://digitalcommons.unl.edu/andrillrespub/62/}} She also participates in collaborative investigations into the modern controls on phytoplankton community structure.{{Cite web|url=https://vimeo.com/138180617|title=2015 For Women In Science Fellow: Dr Christina Riesselman|website=Vimeo|access-date=2016-06-06}} ==Awards and honors== Riesselman won the inaugural [[L'Oréal#Community involvement and awards|L’Oréal]]-[[UNESCO#Official list of UNESCO prizes|UNESCO Fellowship]] for Women in Science New Zealand in 2015.{{Cite news|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=11509783|title=Kiwi geologist Dr Christina Riesselman wins $25,000 fellowship|date=2015-09-08|newspaper=New Zealand Herald|language=en-NZ|issn=1170-0777|access-date=2016-06-05}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.sciencemediacentre.co.nz/2015/09/09/dr-christina-riesselman-awarded-women-in-science-fellowship/|title=Dr Christina Riesselman awarded Women in Science fellowship|date=2015-09-09|access-date=2016-06-05}} ==References== {{reflist|35em}} ==External links== * [http://www.otago.ac.nz/geology/staff/academic/christina-riesselman.html Christina Riesselman's webpage] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Riesselmann, Christina}} [[Category:American women scientists]] [[Category:American oceanographers]] [[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:University of Otago faculty]] [[Category:Antarctic scientists]] [[Category:Women Antarctic scientists]] [[Category:Place of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:Women oceanographers]]

page.title: Coat of arms of San Marino

revision.text:
{{Infobox coat of arms |name = Coat of arms of San Marino |image = Coat of arms of San Marino.svg |image_width = 200 |middle = Coat of arms of San Marino (before 2011).svg |middle_width = 200 |middle_caption = Coat of Arms of San Marino prior to the 2011 standardization. |lesser = |lesser_width = |lesser_caption = |image2 = |image2_width = |image2_caption = |image3 = |image3_width = |image3_caption = |armiger = [[Republic of San Marino]] |year_adopted = 14th century |crest = A Crown of the Republic |torse = |shield = Azure on three mountain tops vert three towers argent masoned and windowed sable each weather vaned with an ostrich plume argent |supporters = Wreath of [[Laurel wreath|laurel]] and [[oak]] |compartment = |motto = '''Libertas'''
"Liberty" |orders = |other_elements = |earlier_versions = |use = }} The '''[[coat of arms]] of [[San Marino]]''' probably originated in the fourteenth century. The official establishment took place on 6 April 1862 by a Decree of the Supreme Council; the same act introduced the crown on top of the shield.[http://www.esteri.sm/contents/instance2/files/document/RSMSCHEDAPAESE.pdf About the Republic of San Marino], p. 6. There is little evidence regarding the official design until the mid-20th century. "[[The Flag Bulletin]]" vol. III, no. 2 from the winter of 1963–64 is reproducing on page 31 an ''"official plate showing the [[Flag of San Marino|flag]] and arms of San Marino, [which] was a gift of the [[Congress of State|Sammarinese government]], through its Consul in [[New York City]]."'' This plate was previously published in an official guide of the republic, from March 1963.Giuseppe Rossi et al., ''Serenissima Repubblica di San Marino - Guida Ufficiale'', Editrice VOGARTE, San Marino, March 1963 In 2011, a new ''Law on the flag and coat of arms of San Marino'' presented a slightly simplified design, the main changes being that the branches have no more ramifications, the towers are square instead of round, and the gates are oriented now towards ''sinister''. The coat of arms of San Marino adorns among other things the [[flag of San Marino|flag of the country]] and the logo of the [[San Marino Football Federation]]. ==Description== The official description of the coat of arms is: {{quote|"The official coat of arms of the Republic is surmounted by a closed [[crown (heraldry)|crown]], the symbol of sovereignty The shield is azure, three mountains vert, towers argent, windowed, embattled and masoned sable, surmounted by [[ostrich]] plumes argent. The shield is surrounded by two branches vert, overlapped in [[saltire]] below the shield, one of [[Laurel wreath|laurel]], the other of [[oak]], fructed or. On a ribbon argent the [[motto]] ''LIBERTAS'' in capital letters sable."}} The components of the coat of arms are in detail: *In the blue shield there are three green mountains with three silver towers, each decorated with a [[weather vane]] consisting of a silver ostrich feather. The towers symbolize the three citadels of San Marino ([[Guaita|La Guaita]], [[La Cesta]] and [[Montale (San Marino)|La Montale]]), while the hills represent the three summits of [[Monte Titano]]. *The motto "LIBERTAS" ([[Latin|Lat.]] ''freedom''). It possibly refers to the taking in of victims of political persecution in the earlier years of San Marino, and to the amazing maintenance of independence in the midst of many larger states. The motto could also have developed from the alleged last words of the founder Marinus: "''Relinquo vos liberos ab utroque homine''" (Lat. "I leave you free from both men").This somewhat mysterious phrase is most likely to refer to the two "men" from whose oppressive power Saint Marinus had decided to separate himself, becoming a hermit on Mount Titano: respectively, the Emperor and the Pope. This affirmation of freedom (first and foremost fiscal franchise) from both the State and the Church, however legendary, has always been the inspiration of the tiny republic. (source: "[https://www.jstor.org/stable/1834173 The Republic of San Marino]", William Miller, The American Historical Review, Vol. 6, No. 4 (Jul., 1901), pp. 633-649) *An oak and laurel branch, which surrounds the coat of arms are symbols for the stability of the republic and the defense of the liberty. *A [[Crown (heraldry)|crown]], which serves as symbol of sovereignty. ==Notes and references== {{reflist|2}} ==See also== * [[Saint Marinus]] * [[Flag of San Marino]] * [[The Three Towers of San Marino]] ==External links== *[http://www.consigliograndeegenerale.sm/on-line/Home/LavoriConsiliari/Dettaglidelleconvocazioni/documento17044527.html Law on the flag and coat of arms of San Marino] {{San Marino topics}} {{Coats of arms of Europe}} [[Category:National coats of arms|San Marino]] [[Category:National symbols of San Marino]] [[Category:Coats of arms with crosses|San Marino]] [[Category:Coats of arms with crowns|San Marino]] [[Category:Coats of arms with buildings|San Marino]] [[Category:Coats of arms with oak branches|San Marino]] [[Category:Coats of arms with mountains|San Marino]] {{SanMarino-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox song contest entry | song = {{flagicon|Portugal}} "Dai li dou" | image = | caption = | year = 1978 | country = Portugal | artist = Fatima Padinha,
Teresa Miguel,
Tozé Brito,
Mike Seargent | as = [[Gemini (Portuguese band)|Gemini]] | with = | language = Portuguese | languages = | composer = Vítor Mamede | lyricist = Carlos Quintas | conductor = Thilo Krassman | place = 17th | points = 5 | lyrics = [http://www.diggiloo.net/?1978pt from Diggiloo Thrush] | prev = Portugal no coração | prev_link = Portugal no coração | next = Sobe, sobe, balão sobe | next_link = Sobe, sobe, balão sobe }} '''Dai li dou''', or alternatively '''Dai-li-dou''' as it is listed in the official Eurovision website, was the [[Portugal|Portuguese]] entry in the [[Eurovision Song Contest 1978]], performed in [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]] by [[Gemini (Portuguese band)|Gemini]]. The song is a moderately up-tempo number, with the band describing the freedom of a kite flying above them. They sing about their own desires for freedom, which they describe as being reflected in the kite. The song was performed fifth on the night, following [[Finland]]'s [[Seija Simola]] with "[[Anna rakkaudelle tilaisuus]]" and preceding [[France]]'s [[Joël Prévost]] with "[[Il y aura toujours des violons]]". At the close of voting, it had received 5 points, placing 17th in a field of 20. It was succeeded as [[Portugal in the Eurovision Song Contest|Portuguese representative]] at the [[Eurovision Song Contest 1979|1979 contest]] by [[Manuela Bravo]] with "[[Sobe, sobe, balão sobe]]". ==References and external links== * [http://www.eurovision.tv/page/history/by-year/contest?event=294 Official Eurovision Song Contest site, history by year, 1978] {{Eurovision Song Contest 1978}} {{Portugal in the Eurovision Song Contest}} {{portugal-stub}} [[Category:Eurovision songs of Portugal]] [[Category:1978 songs]] [[Category:Portuguese-language songs]]

{{unreferenced|date=December 2015}} '''ESPN College Extra''' is an American [[out-of-market sports package]]. It was launched on August 28, 2015 as a merger of the existing [[ESPN Full Court]] and [[ESPN GamePlan]], each of which offered [[college basketball]] and [[college football]] broadcasts respectively.
ESPN College Extra broadcasts College Football from the [[Atlantic Coast Conference|ACC]], [[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]] [[Football Championship Subdivision|FCS]] and [[NCAA Division II]].
==Availability== ESPN College Extra is available with these cable and satellite providers: * [[DirecTV]] * [[Charter Communications|Spectrum]] * [[AT&T U-verse]] * [[Verizon FiOS]]
Almost all ESPN College Extra broadcasts are also made available through [[ESPN3]].
==See also== * [[NFL Sunday Ticket]] * [[NBA League Pass]] * [[NHL Center Ice]] * [[NASCAR Hot Pass]] * [[MLS Direct Kick]] * [[MLB Extra Innings]]
==References== {{Sports television in the United States}} {{U.S. premium television services}} {{ESPN}}

[[Title 15 of the United States Code|15 U.S.C.: Commerce and Trade]] | sections created = | sections amended = | leghisturl = https://www.congress.gov/bill/115th-congress/senate-bill/2155 | introducedin = Senate | introducedbill = "Economic Growth, Regulatory Relief, and Consumer Protection Act" ({{USBill|115|S.|2155}}) | introducedby = [[Mike Crapo]] ([[Republican Party (United States)|R]]–[[Idaho|ID]]) | introduceddate = November 16, 2017 | committees = [[United States Senate Committee on Banking, Housing, and Urban Affairs|Banking]] | passedbody1= Senate with amendment 67-31 | passeddate1= March 14, 2018 | passedvote1= [https://www.senate.gov/legislative/LIS/roll_call_lists/roll_call_vote_cfm.cfm?congress=115&session=2&vote=00054] | passedbody2= House 258-159 | passeddate2= May 22, 2018 | passedvote2= [http://clerk.house.gov/evs/2018/roll216.xml] | signedpresident = [[Donald Trump]] | signeddate = May 24, 2018 | amendments = | SCOTUS cases = }} The '''Economic Growth, Regulatory Relief and Consumer Protection Act''' ({{USPL|115|174}}, {{USBill|115|S.|2155}}) was signed into United States [[Law of the United States#Federal law|federal law]] by [[President of the United States|President]] [[Donald Trump]] on May 24, 2018.{{cite web|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2018/05/24/trump-signs-bank-bill-rolling-back-some-dodd-frank-regulations.html|website=cnbc.com|title=Trump signs bank bill rolling back some Dodd-Frank regulations|accessdate=2018-05-24}} The bill eases regulations imposed by Dodd-Frank after the [[financial crisis of 2007–2008]] by raising the threshold to $250 billion from $50 billion under which banks are deemed too important to the financial system to fail. ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:United States federal banking legislation]] [[Category:Systemic risk]] [[Category:115th United States Congress]] [[Category:Presidency of Donald Trump]] [[Category:2018 in American law]] [[Category:2018 in economics]] {{US-law-stub}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2013}} {{Use Indian English|date=July 2015}} {{Cleanup|reason=repeated information and poor organisation|date=August 2014}} The '''economic liberalisation in India''' refers to the [[economic liberalisation|changes and reforms]], initiated in 1991, of the country's economic policies, with the goal of making the economy more market- and service-oriented, and expanding the role of private and foreign investment.<ref name="originalreport">{{cite web |title=India - Structural Adjustment Credit Project (English) - Presidents report |url=http://documents.worldbank.org/curated/en/999451468260069468/India-Structural-Adjustment-Credit-Project |website=www.documents.worldbank.org |publisher=World bank |accessdate=30 October 2018}}</ref> Most of these changes were made as part of the conditions laid out by the [[World Bank]] and the [[IMF]] as a condition for a $500 million bail out to the Indian government in December 1991.<ref name="worldbank">{{cite web |title=Structural adjustments in India - a reportof the Independent Evaluation Group (IEG) |url=http://lnweb90.worldbank.org/oed/oeddoclib.nsf/DocUNIDViewForJavaSearch/0586CC45A28A2749852567F5005D8C89 |website=www.lnweb90.worldbank.org |publisher=World bank |accessdate=30 October 2018}}</ref> Specific changes include a reduction in import tariffs, deregulation of markets, reduction of taxes, and greater foreign investment. Liberalisation has been credited by its proponents for the high economic growth recorded by the country in the 1990s and 2000s. Its opponents have blamed it for increased inequality and economic degradation. The overall direction of liberalisation has since remained the same, irrespective of the ruling party, although no party has yet solved a variety of politically difficult issues, such as liberalising labour laws and reducing [[subsidies in India|agricultural subsidies]].<ref name="Gandhi-1">{{cite news |title=That old Gandhi magic |date=27 November 1997 |work=The Economist |url=http://www.economist.com/node/107076}}</ref> There exists a lively debate in India as to whether the economic reforms were sustainable and beneficial to the people of India as a whole.<ref>For a critique of the existing explanations and a comprehensive alternative explanation see: Sharma, Chanchal Kumar (2011) "[http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/14736489.2011.574550 A Discursive Dominance Theory of Economic Reforms Sustainability]." ''India Review'' (Routledge, UK) 126–84</ref><ref name="WB2">{{cite web |title=Project proposal - Structured adjustment of India |url=http://documents.worldbank.org/curated/en/999451468260069468/India-Structural-Adjustment-Credit-Project |website=www.documents.worldbank.org |publisher=World Bank |accessdate=30 October 2018}}</ref>
Indian government coalitions have been advised by the IMF and World Bank to continue liberalisation. Before 2015, India grew at a slower pace than [[People's Republic of China|China]], which had been [[Chinese economic reform|liberalising its economy]] since 1978.<ref name="holdingback">{{cite news |url=http://www.economist.com/opinion/displaystory.cfm?story_id=10808493 |title=India's economy: What's holding India back? |date=6 March 2008 |work=The Economist}}</ref> In 2015, India's GDP growth outpaced that of China.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/business-35519671|title=India outpaces China in 2015 economic growth |publisher= BBC News}}</ref> ''The McKinsey Quarterly'' stated that removing major obstacles "would free India's economy to grow as fast as China's, at 10% a year".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://business.indian-network.de/artikel/The%20McKinsey%20Quarterly-%20India-From%20emerging%20to%20surging.pdf |title=The McKinsey Quarterly: India – From emerging to surging |publisher=The McKinsey Quarterly |year=2001}}</ref>
There has been significant debate, however, around liberalisation as an inclusive economic growth strategy. Income inequality has deepened in India since 1992, with consumption among the poorest staying stable while the wealthiest generate consumption growth.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/Indias-income-inequality-has-doubled-in-20-years/articleshow/11012855.cms |title=India's income inequality has doubled in 20 years |publisher= The Times of India |website=Timesofindia.indiatimes.com |date= |accessdate=2013-07-10}}</ref> India's [[gross domestic product]] (GDP) growth rate in 2012–13 was the lowest for a decade, at just 5.1%,<ref>[http://www.thehindubusinessline.com/economy/gdp-growth-slumps-to-5-a-decades-low/article4768550.ece GDP growth slumps to 5%, a decade’s low], Hindu Business Line 31 May 2013</ref> at which time more criticism of India's economic reforms surfaced; it apparently failed to address employment growth, nutritional values in terms of food intake in calories, and also export growth—and thereby was leading to a worsening [[current account deficit]] compared to the period prior to reform.<ref>[http://www.eastasiaforum.org/2013/06/04/indias-ponzi-styled-economic-reforms-run-out-of-steam/ India’s Ponzi-styled economic reforms run out of steam], East Asia Forum 4 June 2013</ref> The country continues to perform poorly in all developmental aspects, with high unemployment among the youth, poor women's security, rampant corruption, the highest number of malnourished children and poor sanitation.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Joseph |first1=Josy |title=A feast of vultures |date=1 July 2016 |location=New Delhi |accessdate=30 October 2018}}</ref>
==Pre-liberalisation policies== {{History of modern India}} {{Further|Economic history of India|Licence Raj}}
Indian [[economic policy]] after [[Indian independence movement|independence]] was influenced by the colonial experience (which was seen by Indian leaders as exploitative in nature) and by those leaders' exposure to [[Fabian socialism]]. Policy tended towards [[protectionist|protectionism]], with a strong emphasis on [[import substitution industrialization]] under state monitoring, [[state intervention]] at the micro level in all businesses especially in labour and financial markets, a large public sector, business regulation, and [[central planning]].<ref name="kirit-1">{{cite journal|author1=Kelegama, Saman|author2=Parikh, Kirit|title=Political Economy of Growth and Reforms in South Asia|year=2000|version=Second Draft|url=http://www.eldis.org/static/DOC12473.htm|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060211121955/http://www.eldis.org/static/DOC12473.htm|archivedate=11 February 2006|df=dmy-all}}</ref> [[Five-Year Plans of India]] resembled central planning in the [[Soviet Union]]. Steel, mining, machine tools, water, telecommunications, insurance, and electrical plants, among other industries, were effectively nationalised in the mid-1950s.<ref name="staley">{{cite web|url=http://www.reason.com/news/show/36682.html|title=The Rise and Fall of Indian Socialism: Why India embraced economic reform|author=Sam Staley|year=2006}}</ref> Elaborate licences, regulations and the accompanying [[red tape]], commonly referred to as [[Licence Raj]], were required to set up business in [[India]] between 1947 and 1990.<ref>[http://www.swaminomics.org/articles/20011125_streethawking.htm Street Hawking Promise Jobs in Future] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080329023451/http://www.swaminomics.org/articles/20011125_streethawking.htm |date=29 March 2008 }}, [[The Times of India]], 25 November 2001</ref>
{{quotation|Before the process of reform began in 1991, the government attempted to close the Indian economy to the outside world. The Indian currency, the [[Indian rupee|rupee]], was inconvertible and high tariffs and import licensing prevented foreign goods reaching the market.<ref>{{cite web |title=India: 1991 country economic memorandum |url=http://documents.worldbank.org/curated/en/962181468033534646/pdf/multi0page.pdf |website=www.documents.worldbank.org |publisher=World bank |accessdate=30 October 2018}}</ref> India also operated a system of [[central planning]] for the economy, in which firms required licences to invest and develop. The labyrinthine bureaucracy often led to absurd restrictions—up to 80 agencies had to be satisfied before a firm could be granted a licence to produce and the state would decide what was produced, how much, at what price and what sources of capital were used. The government also prevented firms from laying off workers or closing factories. The central pillar of the policy was [[import substitution]], the belief that India needed to rely on internal markets for development, not international trade—a belief generated by a mixture of socialism and the experience of colonial exploitation. Planning and the state, rather than markets, would determine how much investment was needed in which sectors.|[[BBC]]<ref name="bbc1998"/>}}
===Pre-1991 liberalisation attempts=== Attempts were made to liberalise the economy in 1966 and 1985. The first attempt was reversed in 1967. Thereafter, a stronger version of socialism was adopted. The second major attempt was in 1985 by prime minister [[Rajiv Gandhi]]. The process came to a halt in 1987, though a 1967 style reversal did not take place.<ref>For a complete history & analysis of liberalisation episodes in India, see: Sharma, Chanchal Kumar (2011) "[http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/14736489.2011.574550 A Discursive Dominance Theory of Economic Reforms Sustainability]." ''India Review'' (Routledge, UK) 126–84</ref>
In the 80s, the government led by [[Rajiv Gandhi]] started light reforms. The government slightly reduced Licence Raj and also promoted the growth of the telecommunications and software industries.<ref>History of Computing in India: 1955–2010, Rajaraman, V.</ref>
The [[Chandra Shekhar Singh]] government (1990–1991) took several significant steps towards the much needed reforms and laid its foundation.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://epaper.newindianexpress.com/c/8158805 | title=New Indian Express | accessdate=18 January 2016 | website=New Indian Express}}</ref>
===Prevailing situation during 1980s=== * The low annual growth rate of the [[economy of India]] before 1980, which stagnated around 3.5% from 1950s to 1980s, while per capita income averaged 1.3%.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.financialexpress.com/news/redefining-the-hindu-rate-of-growth/104268/|title=Redefining The Hindu Rate of Growth|work=The Financial Express }}</ref> At the same time, [[Pakistan]] grew by 5%, [[Indonesia]] by 9%, [[Thailand]] by 9%, [[South Korea]] by 10% and [[Taiwan]] by 12%.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tribuneindia.com/50yrs/kapur.htm|title=Industry passing through phase of transition|publisher=The Tribune India}}</ref> * Only four or five licences would be given for steel, electrical power and communications. Licence owners built up huge powerful empires.<ref name="bbc1998">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/south_asia/55427.stm|title=India: the economy|publisher=BBC | date=12 February 1998}}</ref> * A huge private sector emerged. State-owned enterprises made large losses.<ref name="bbc1998"/> * Income Tax Department and Customs Department became inefficient in checking tax evasion.{{citation needed|reason=Your explanation here|date=January 2016}} * Infrastructure investment was poor because of the public sector monopoly.<ref name="bbc1998"/> * Licence Raj established the "irresponsible, self-perpetuating bureaucracy that still exists throughout much of the country"<ref name="makar">{{cite book|title=An American's Guide to Doing Business in India|author=Eugene M. Makar|year=2007}}</ref> and corruption flourished under this system.<ref name="astaire"/>
The fruits of liberalisation reached their peak in 2006, when India recorded its highest GDP growth rate of 9.6%.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/in.html#Econ |title=The World Factbook |publisher=Cia.gov |date= |accessdate=2013-07-10}}</ref> With this, India became the second fastest growing major economy in the world, next only to China.<ref name="astaire">{{cite web|url=http://www.ukibc.com/ukindia2/files/India60.pdf |title=The India Report |publisher=Astaire Research |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090114195859/http://www.ukibc.com/ukindia2/files/India60.pdf |archivedate=14 January 2009 |df=dmy }}</ref> The growth rate has slowed significantly in the first half of 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-18275858 |title=India growth rate slows to 5.3% in first quarter |publisher=BBC.co.uk |date=2012-05-31 |accessdate=2013-07-10}}</ref> An [[Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development]] (OECD) report states that the average growth rate 7.5% will double the average income in a decade, and more reforms would speed up the pace.<ref name="oecdindia2007">{{cite web|url=http://www.oecd.org/dataoecd/17/52/39452196.pdf|title=Economic survey of India 2007: Policy Brief|publisher=OECD|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110606000000/http://www.oecd.org/dataoecd/17/52/39452196.pdf|archivedate=6 June 2011|df=dmy-all}}</ref> The economy then rebounded to 7.3% growth in 2014–15.
==First reforms (1991–96)== {{multiple image | align = right | image1 = Pumapaparti.N.rao.jpg | width1 = 125 | alt1 = P. V. Narasimha Rao | link1 = P. V. Narasimha Rao | caption1 = <center>'''[[P. V. Narasimha Rao]]'''</center> | image2 = Manmohansingh04052007.jpg | width2 = 100 | alt2 = Manmohan Singh | link2 = Manmohan Singh | caption2 = <center>'''[[Manmohan Singh]]'''</center> | footer = Economic liberalisation in India was initiated in 1991 by Prime Minister P. V. Narasimha Rao and his then-Finance Minister Dr. Manmohan Singh.<ref name="Reforming">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/south_asia/4120429.stm|title=Narasimha Rao – a Reforming PM|work=news.bbc.co.uk|publisher=[[BBC News]]|date=23 December 2004|accessdate=2 March 2007}}</ref> Rao was often referred to as ''[[Chanakya]]'' for his ability to steer tough economic and political legislation through the parliament at a time when he headed a [[minority government]].<ref name="frontline">{{cite journal |url=http://www.hindu.com/thehindu/thscrip/print.pl?file=20050114008013000.htm&date=fl2201/&prd=fline& |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100130013320/http://www.hinduonnet.com/fline/fl2201/stories/20050114008013000.htm |archivedate=2010-01-30 |title=Obituary: A scholar and a politician|author=V. Venkatesan |journal=Frontline |volume=22 |issue=1 |date=1–14 January 2005 |accessdate=30 March 2010}}</ref><ref>[http://www.tlca.com/adults/obit-pvn.html PV Narasimha Rao Passes Away]. Retrieved 7 October 2007. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071101063203/http://www.tlca.com/adults/obit-pvn.html |date=1 November 2007 }}</ref> }}
===Crisis=== {{Main|1991 India economic crisis}} By 1991, India still had a fixed [[exchange rate]] system, where the rupee was pegged to the value of a basket of currencies of major trading partners. India started having [[balance of payments]] problems since 1985, and by the end of 1990, the state of India was in a serious [[economic crisis]]. The government was close to default,<ref name="Ghosh">[http://www.globaleconomicgovernance.org/wp-content/uploads/Ghosh%20-%20India.pdf India's Pathway through Financial Crisis] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111112080531/http://www.globaleconomicgovernance.org/wp-content/uploads/Ghosh%20-%20India.pdf |date=12 November 2011 }}. [[Arunabha Ghosh]]. Global Economic Governance Programme. Retrieved on 2 March 2007.</ref><ref name="IMF">[http://www.uoit.ca/sas/Macroeconomic%20Issues/What1991CrisisIndia.pdf What Caused the 1991 Currency Crisis in India?], IMF Staff Papers, Valerie Cerra and Sweta Chaman Saxena.</ref> its central bank had refused new credit and [[foreign exchange reserves]] had reduced to the point that India could barely finance three weeks’ worth of imports. It had to pledge 20 tonnes of gold to Union Bank of Switzerland and 47 tonnes to Bank of England as part of a bailout deal with the International Monetary Fund (IMF). Most of the economic reforms were forced upon India as a part of the IMF bailout.<ref name = "reform">[https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/29/world/economic-crisis-forcing-once-self-reliant-india-to-seek-aid.html Economic Crisis Forcing Once Self-Reliant India to Seek Aid], New York Times, 29 June 1991</ref>
{{quotation|A Balance of Payments crisis in 1991 pushed the country to near bankruptcy. In return for an IMF bailout, gold was transferred to London as collateral, the rupee devalued and economic reforms were forced upon India. That low point was the catalyst required to transform the economy through badly needed reforms to unshackle the economy. Controls started to be dismantled, tariffs, duties and taxes progressively lowered, state monopolies broken, the economy was opened to trade and investment, [[private sector enterprise]] and competition were encouraged and [[globalisation]] was slowly embraced. The reforms process continues today and is accepted by all political parties, but the speed is often held hostage by coalition politics and vested interests.|India Report, Astaire Research<ref name="astaire"/>}}
==Liberalisation of 1991 and World Bank loan==
In response, Prime Minister [[Narasimha Rao]], along with his finance minister [[Manmohan Singh]], initiated the [[Economic reforms in India|economic liberalisation of 1991]]. The reforms did away with the [[Licence Raj]], reduced tariffs and interest rates and ended many public monopolies, allowing automatic approval of [[foreign direct investment]] in many sectors.{{sfn|Task Force Report|2006|pp=7–8}} Since then, the overall thrust of liberalisation has remained the same, although no government has tried to take on powerful lobbies such as trade unions and farmers, on contentious issues such as reforming labour laws and reducing [[agricultural subsidy|agricultural subsidies]].<ref name="Gandhi-2">{{cite news|title=That old Gandhi magic|date= 27 November 1997|work=The Economist|url=http://www.economist.com/world/asia/displaystory.cfm?story_id=107076|accessdate=2011-01-17}}</ref> By the turn of the 21st century, India had progressed towards a free-market economy, with a substantial reduction in state control of the economy and increased financial liberalisation.<ref>{{Harvnb|Kumar|2005|p=1037}}</ref> This has been accompanied by increases in life expectancy, literacy rates and food security, although urban residents have benefited more than rural residents.{{sfn|Task Force Report|2006|pp=17–20}}
On 12 November 1991, based on an application from the Government of India, World Bank sanctioned a structural adjustment loan / credit that consisted of two components - an IBRD loan of $250 million to be paid over 20 years, and an IDA credit of SDR 183.8 million (equivalent to $250 million) with 35 years maturity, through India's ministry of finance, with the President of India as the borrower. The loan was meant primarily to support the government's program of stabilization and economic reform. This specified deregulation, increased foreign direct investment, liberalization of the trade regime, reforming domestic interest rates, strengthening capital markets (stock exchanges), and initiating public enterprise reform (selling off public enterprises).<ref name="1991wbreport">{{cite web |title=World bank report P-5678-IN - report of the IBRD and IDA on a proposed structural adjustment loan to India |url=http://documents.worldbank.org/curated/en/999451468260069468/pdf/multi0page.pdf |website=www.documents.worldbank.org |publisher=World bank official website |accessdate=30 October 2018}}</ref>
==Later reforms== {{Expand list|date=April 2009}} * The [[Bharatiya Janata Party]] (BJP)–[[Atal Bihari Vajpayee]] administration surprised many by continuing reforms, when it was at the helm of affairs of India for six years, from 1998–99 and from 1999–2004.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.j-bradford-delong.net/Econ_Articles/India/India_Rodrik_DeLong.PDF|title=India Since Independence: An Analytic Growth Narrative|author=J. Bradford DeLong|year=2001}}</ref> * The BJP-led [[National Democratic Alliance (India)|National Democratic Alliance]] Coalition began privatising under-performing government owned business including hotels, [[VSNL]], [[Maruti Suzuki]], and airports, and began reduction of taxes, an overall [[fiscal policy]] aimed at reducing deficits and debts and increased initiatives for public works. * The [[United Front (India)|United Front]] government attempted a progressive budget that encouraged reforms, but the [[1997 Asian financial crisis]] and [[political instability]] created [[economic stagnation]]. * Towards the end of 2011, the Congress-led UPA-2 Coalition Government initiated the introduction of 51% [[Foreign Direct Investment]] in retail sector. But due to pressure from fellow coalition parties and the opposition, the decision was rolled back. However, it was approved in December 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://zeenews.india.com/business/news/economy/govt-approves-51-fdi-in-multi-brand-retail_60309.html |title=End of policy paralysis: Govt approves 51% FDI in multi-brand retail |publisher=Zeenews.india.com |date= |accessdate=2013-07-10}}</ref> * In the early months of 2015, the second BJP-led NDA Government under [[Narendra Modi]] further opened up the insurance sector by allowing up to 49% FDI. This came seven years after the previous government attempted and failed to push through the same reforms and 16 years after the sector was first opened to foreign investors up to 26% under the first BJP-led NDA Government under Atal Bihari Vajpayee's administration.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.livemint.com/Politics/p78kNkYr1XPA92LXLUwoBP/Insurance-Bill-passed-in-Rajya-Sabha.html |title= Parliament passes insurance bill in a major boost to Modi's reforms agenda|publisher=livemint.com |date= |accessdate=2015-03-13}}</ref> * The second BJP-led NDA Government also opened up the coal industry through the passing of the Coal Mines (Special Provisions) Bill of 2015. It effectively ended the Indian central government's monopoly over the mining of coal, which existed since nationalization in 1973 through socialist controls. It has opened up the path for private, foreign investments in the sector, since Indian arms of foreign companies are entitled to bid for coal blocks and licences, as well as for commercial mining of coal. This could result in billions of dollars investments by domestic and foreign miners. The move is also beneficial to the state-owned Coal India Limited, which may now get the elbow room to bring in some much needed technology and best practices, while opening up prospects of a better future for millions of mine workers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.indiatoday.intoday.in/story/rajya-sabha-passes-coal-mining-bill-coal-mines-bill-2015-budget-session-of-parliament/1/424931.html |title= Parliament boost to Modi's plans: Coal, mining bills passed by Rajya Sabha|publisher=indiatoday.intotoday.in |date= |accessdate=2015-03-29}}</ref> * In the 2016 budget session of Parliament, the Narendra Modi led BJP Government pushed through the Insolvency and Bankruptcy Code. The Code creates time-bound processes for insolvency resolution of companies and individuals. These processes will be completed within 180 days. If insolvency cannot be resolved, the assets of the borrowers may be sold to repay creditors. This law drastically eases the process of doing business, according to experts and is considered by many to be the second most important reform in India since 1991 next to the proposed GST.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/economy/policy/bankruptcy-code-biggest-economic-reform-after-gst-finance-ministry/articleshow/52228931.cms|title=Bankruptcy code biggest economic reform after GST: Finance Ministry|date=|accessdate=2016-05-11}}</ref> * On July 1st 2017, the BJP-led NDA Government under Narendra Modi launched the [[Goods and Services Tax (India)]]. This came years after the previous government attempted and failed to push through the same reform and 17 years after the legislation was proposed under the first BJP-led NDA Government under Atal Bihari Vajpayee's administration in 2000. Touted to be India's biggest tax reform in 70 years of independence and the most important overall reform in terms of ease of doing business since 1991. GST replaces a slew of indirect taxes with a unified tax structure and is therefore set to dramatically reshape the country's 2.5 trillion dollar economy.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/india-news/gst-launch-times-when-the-parliament-convened-for-a-session-at-midnight/story-c55g94ewrOMefUvQJVFSEO.html |title= GST Launch Time Midnight Parliament Session|publisher=Hindustantimes.com |date= |accessdate=2017-07-20}}</ref>
==Impact== {{Refimprove section|date=December 2015}} [[File:HSBC GLT PUNE.jpg|thumb|right|HSBC GLT, [[Pune]]]] The economic liberalization of India had a multitude of impacts, some of which were positive and others negative for its people. The foreign investment in the country (including [[foreign direct investment]], [[portfolio investment]], and investment raised on international capital markets]) increased from a minuscule US$132 million in 1991–92 to $5.3 billion in 1995–96.<ref name="Asiaweek">[http://www.asiaweek.com/asiaweek/96/0412/nat1.html Local industrialists against multinationals]. Ajay Singh and Arjuna Ranawana. ''[[Asiaweek]]''. Retrieved on 2 March 2007.</ref> On the other hand, it also enabled a number of companies like [[Enron]] to [[Dabhol Power Company|invest]] more easily in India, in over expensive projects.<ref name="roy">{{cite news|last1=Roy|first1=Sandip|title=Enron in India - The giant's first fall|url=http://www.alternet.org/story/12375/enron_in_india%3A_the_giant%27s_first_fall|accessdate=25 October 2016|agency=Pacific news Service|issue=March 2002|publisher=Outlook|date=7 February 2002}}</ref> As per the US Senate, the largest share of foreign direct investment in India since 1992 came from Enron (more than 10%).<ref>{{cite news |title=118High-Stakes Showdown; Enron’s Fight Over Power Plant Reverberates Beyond India |url=http://www.finance-mba.com/Dabhol_fact_sheet.pdf |accessdate=26 November 2018 |publisher=New York Times |date=20 March 2001}}</ref>
However, financial institutions applauded it:
{{quotation| Its annual growth in [[GDP per capita]] accelerated from just 1¼ per cent in the three decades after Independence to 7½ per cent currently, a rate of growth that will double average income in a decade.... In service sectors where government regulation has been eased significantly or is less burdensome—such as communications, insurance, asset management and information technology—output has grown rapidly, with exports of [[information technology enabled services]] particularly strong. In those infrastructure sectors which have been opened to competition, such as [[telecoms]] and [[civil aviation]], the private sector has proven to be extremely effective and growth has been phenomenal.|[[OECD]]<ref name="oecdindia2007"/>}}
Election of AB Vajpayee as Prime Minister of India in 1998 and his agenda was seen as a welcome change by some. His prescription to speed up economic progress included solution of all outstanding problems with the West (Cold War related) and then opening gates for FDI investment. In three years, the West was developing a bit of a fascination to India's brainpower, powered by IT and BPO. By 2004, the West would consider investment in India, should the conditions permit. By the end of Vajpayee's term as prime minister, a framework for the foreign investment had been established. The new incoming government of Dr. Manmohan Singh in 2004 further strengthened the required infrastructure to welcome the FDI.
Today, fascination with India is translating into active consideration of India as a destination for FDI. A study by A T Kearney named India as the second most likely destination for FDI in 2005 after China. It has displaced US to the third position. This is a great leap forward. India was at the 15th position, only a few years back. To quote the A T Kearney Study, "India's strong performance among manufacturing and telecom & utility firms was driven largely by their desire to make productivity-enhancing investments in IT, business process outsourcing, research and development, and knowledge management activities".
==Challenges to further reforms== For 2010, India was ranked 124th among 179 countries in [[Index of Economic Freedom]] World Rankings, which is an improvement from the preceding year. * Slow growth of the [[Agriculture in India|agricultural sector]], a sector in which where more than half of India's population works<ref name="bbchal" /> * [[Indian labour law|Highly restrictive and complex labour laws]].<ref name="oecdindia2007"/><ref name="more reform">{{cite web|url=http://news.indiainfo.com/2006/04/20/2004imf-labour-laws.html|title=IMF calls for urgent reform in Indian labour laws}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.worldbank.org/html/prdph/downsize/docs/india.pdf|title=Retrenchment, Labor Laws and Government Policy: An Analysis with Special Reference to India|author=[[Kaushik Basu]], Gary S. Fields, and [[Shub Debgupta]]|publisher=The World Bank}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://atlmri.googlepages.com/RCD_MILI.pdf|title=Contemporary Issues on Labour Law Reform in India|author=[[R. C. Datta]]/[[Milly Sil]]|year=2007}}</ref><ref name="[[gupta]]">{{cite web|url=http://www.ccsindia.org/interns2006/How%20Wrong%20is%20left%20about%20ecoonimic%20reforms%20in%20India%20-%20Aditya.pdf|archive-url=http://wayback.archive-it.org/all/20090226070930/http://www.ccsindia.org/interns2006/How%20Wrong%20is%20left%20about%20ecoonimic%20reforms%20in%20India%20-%20Aditya.pdf|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2009-02-26|title=How wrong has the Indian Left been about economic reforms?|author=[[Aditya Gupta]]|year=2006}}</ref><ref name="[[indialabourlawbbc]]">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/south_asia/4103554.stm|title=Why India needs labour law reform|publisher=BBC | date=27 June 2005|first=Kaushik|last=Basu}}</ref><ref name="[[ppindiaelephant]]">{{cite news|url=http://www.economist.com/specialreports/displayStory.cfm?story_id=12749735|title=A special report on India: An elephant, not a tiger|date=11 December 2008|work=The Economist}}</ref><ref name="wbindiaoverview2008">{{cite web|url=http://www.worldbank.org.in/WBSITE/EXTERNAL/COUNTRIES/SOUTHASIAEXT/INDIAEXTN/0,,contentMDK:20195738~menuPK:295591~pagePK:141137~piPK:141127~theSitePK:295584,00.html|title=India Country Overview 2008|year=2008|publisher=The World Bank}}</ref><ref name="indiamodel">{{cite web|url=http://www.foreignaffairs.org/20060701faessay85401-p0/gurcharan-das/the-india-model.html|title=The India Model|author=Gurcharan Das|publisher=The Foreign Affairs|date=July–August 2006|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090307101534/http://www.foreignaffairs.org/20060701faessay85401-p0/gurcharan-das/the-india-model.html|archivedate=7 March 2009|df=dmy-all}}</ref> * [[Inflation in India|High inflation]]<ref name="bbchal">{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-south-asia-14300534|title=Challenges ahead for India reforms|last=Biswas|first=Soutik|date=2011-07-27|newspaper=BBC News|publisher=BBC|accessdate=2013-12-23|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110908094808/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-south-asia-14300534|archivedate=2011-09-08|deadurl=no}}</ref> * [[Poverty in India|High poverty]]<ref name="bbchal" /> * [[Corruption in India|Corruption]] and [[graft (politics)|graft]]<ref name="bbchal" /> * Lack of political consensus and will<ref name="bbchal" /><ref name="timechal">{{cite news|url=http://business.time.com/2012/11/15/india-vs-china-which-has-a-bigger-reform-challenge/|newspaper=Time|publisher=Time|title=India vs China: Which Has a Bigger Reform Challenge?|date=2012-11-05|accessdate=2013-12-23|first=Michael|last=Schuman|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130309193542/http://business.time.com/2012/11/15/india-vs-china-which-has-a-bigger-reform-challenge/|archivedate=2013-03-09|deadurl=no}}</ref>
[[OECD]] summarised the key reforms that are needed: {{quotation|In labour markets, employment growth has been concentrated in firms that operate in sectors not covered by India's highly restrictive labour laws. In the formal sector, where these labour laws apply, employment has been falling and firms are becoming more [[capital intensive]] despite abundant low-cost labour. [[Labour market reform]] is essential to achieve a broader-based development and provide sufficient and higher productivity jobs for the growing labour force. In product markets, inefficient government procedures, particularly in some of the states, acts as a barrier to entrepreneurship and need to be improved. Public companies are generally less productive than private firms and the privatisation programme should be revitalised. A number of barriers to competition in financial markets and some of the infrastructure sectors, which are other constraints on growth, also need to be addressed. The [[indirect tax]] system needs to be simplified to create a true national market, while for direct taxes, the taxable base should be broadened and rates lowered. Public expenditure should be re-oriented towards infrastructure investment by reducing subsidies. Furthermore, social policies should be improved to better reach the poor and—given the importance of human capital—the education system also needs to be made more efficient.|OECD<ref name="oecdindia2007"/>}}
Though recently labour law reforms have been enacted at the state level<ref>{{cite web|url=http://indianexpress.com/article/india/india-others/rajasthan-shows-way-in-labour-reforms/|title=Rajasthan shows way in labour reforms|date=8 June 2014|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.business-standard.com/article/economy-policy/president-okays-rajasthan-labour-reforms-firms-with-300-workers-need-no-govt-nod-to-sack-114110801356_1.html|title=President okays Rajasthan labour reforms: Firms with 300 workers need no govt nod to sack|first=Somesh|last=Jha|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.business-standard.com/article/current-affairs/madhya-pradesh-assembly-passes-labour-law-amendments-115072200606_1.html|title=Madhya Pradesh assembly passes labour law amendments|first=Somesh Jha & Shashikant|last=Trivedi|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.business-standard.com/article/economy-policy/president-clears-madhya-pradesh-labour-reforms-115112401109_1.html|title=President clears Madhya Pradesh labour reforms|first=Somesh|last=Jha|publisher=}}</ref>
===Reforms at the state level=== {{See also|Economic disparities in India}} According to an OECD survey of the Indian economy <ref name="oecdindia2007"/> states that had more liberal regulatory regimes had better economic performance. The survey also concluded that were complementary measures for better delivery of infrastructure, education and basic services implemented, they would boost employment creation and poverty reduction.
==See also== * [[Economy of India]] * [[Globalisation in India]] * [[Licence Raj]] * [[Hindu rate of growth]] * [[Economic miracle]]
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== * For a short educational video of the [http://one.revver.com/watch/339183/flv/affiliate/94378 "economic history of India"]. * {{cite web|url=http://www.reason.com/blog/show/131810.html|title=What Slumdog Millionaire can teach Americans about economic stimulus|year=2009|author=Nick Gillespie|publisher=Reason}} * {{cite web|url=http://www.foreignaffairs.org/20060701faessay85401-p0/gurcharan-das/the-india-model.html|title=The India Model|author=Gurcharan Das|publisher=The Foreign Affairs|year=2006|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090307101534/http://www.foreignaffairs.org/20060701faessay85401-p0/gurcharan-das/the-india-model.html|archivedate=7 March 2009|df=dmy-all}} * {{cite web|url=https://www.academia.edu/12282652/Good_Times_Brought_to_you_by_Brand_Modi|title=Good Times, Brought to you by Brand Modi|author=Ravinder Kaur|publisher=Television and New Media|year=2015}}{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} * {{cite web|url=https://www.academia.edu/3347336/India_Inc._and_its_moral_discontents|title=India Inc. and its Moral Discontent|author=Ravinder Kaur|publisher=Economic and Political Weekly|year=2012}} * {{cite web|url=http://www.ccsindia.org/interns2006/How%20Wrong%20is%20left%20about%20ecoonimic%20reforms%20in%20India%20-%20Aditya.pdf|archive-url=http://wayback.archive-it.org/all/20090226070930/http://www.ccsindia.org/interns2006/How%20Wrong%20is%20left%20about%20ecoonimic%20reforms%20in%20India%20-%20Aditya.pdf|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2009-02-26|title=How wrong has the Indian Left been about economic reforms?|author=Aditya Gupta|publisher=Centre for Civil Society|year=2006}} * {{cite web|url=http://www.ukibc.com/ukindia2/files/India60.pdf |title=The India Report |publisher=Astaire Research <<doesn't work>> |year=2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090114195859/http://www.ukibc.com/ukindia2/files/India60.pdf |archivedate=14 January 2009 |df=dmy }}

The '''Genealogical Society of South Africa''' is a [[family history society]] in South Africa. Founded on 18 June 1964,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~zafgssa/Eng/About.html|title=Founding|publisher=[[Rootsweb]]|accessdate=2009-08-05}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> the society today consists of 10 regional branches as well as an electronic branch accessible online.
The society maintains a large archive of [[Genealogy|Genealogical]] material related to Southern African families.
==See also== * [[Genealogical Institute of South Africa]]
==References== {{reflist}}

revision.text:
'''Kekri''', also known as ''Keyri'', ''Köyri'', ''Köyry'' (in [[Torne Valley]]) and ''Kööri'', is an old annual Finnish society-fashioned [[harvest festival]], celebrated in the fall. The recognition and celebrations of Kekri were stronger when [[Finland]] was still an agricultural society, and prior to the modern Christmas culture and traditions being embedded in the Finnish society. Historically, Kekri has also referred to a god.
Originally, the celebration of Kekri was not tied to a permanent calendar date, but – instead – was determined by the ongoing year's agricultural autumn activities. However, by the early 1800s its date stabilized at the [[All Saints' Day]], i.e. in the beginning of November.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20120716232314/http://www.nba.fi/fi/kansallismuseo/tapahtumat/kekri ]</ref>
==Etymology==
In various Finnish dialects and in vernacular language, the term kekri and its cognates have been used to refer to the last thing left, residue, remnant and/or end of something, most commonly – and possibly originally – the harvest season. Historically, Kekri was a god that protected cattle. The term has also been used in reference to leprechaun/fairy, scare and scarecrow.<ref>[http://web.archive.org/web/20120716232314/http://www.nba.fi/fi/kansallismuseo/tapahtumat/kekri]</ref>
In his listing of Finnish gods in 1551, the Finnish author [[Mikael Agricola]] defined Kekri as a god that enhances the growth of livestock: ''"Käkri se liseis Carjan casvon"''. In his study 'Mythologica fennica' in 1789, [[Cristfried Ganander]] stated the same about Kekri, and added that the term Kekri also refers to the celebration of the end of the harvest season.<ref>''Otavan Suuri Ensyklopedia, Part 4'', Juusten-Kreikka, p. 2854, Otava, 1978, {{ISBN|951-1-02232-6}}.</ref>
The remembrance of the dead is a similarity between the traditional celebrations of Kekri and [[Halloween]]. In the Finnic tradition of the past, each family invited their dead to their Kekri feasts, making a part of Kekri formal and serious. The second day of Kekri – however – has traditionally been more relaxed, similar in this respect to [[Boxing Day]] in the widespread modern Western Christmas tradition. In the second day of Kekri, especially in the old times, people have visited family and friends, dressed up as various types of Kekri characters. These Kekri characters of the past are commonly viewed as predecessors of the modern-day Santa Claus.
Traditionally, the end of the harvest season in Kekri has been celebrated with abundant feasts, which often have included lamb roast as one of the courses served. Various kinds of magic, spells, beliefs and myths too have also been an important part of old Kekri traditions, as well as bonfires, especially in certain parts of Finland.<ref>[http://web.archive.org/web/20120716232314/http://www.nba.fi/fi/kansallismuseo/tapahtumat/kekri]</ref>
==Kekri today==
Kekri traditions began to disappear in [[Finland]] with the industrialization and urbanization of the Finnish society. Many customs and traditions associated with Kekri have since been transferred to the modern Christmas and New Year celebrations.
Some ancient Kekri traditions have remained the longest in Eastern Finland. Today, Kekri is celebrated annually in the Eastern Finnish city of [[Kajaani]] by the burning of the so-called ''Kekri goat'' ([[Finnish language|Finnish]]: Kekripukki), built in the recent times normally by local actors and other players. The incineration of the Kekri goat is usually linked to other program and activities, such as dance and musical performances, street market, feast, etc.
Kekri is celebrated also in other parts of Finland, for instance in the Southern Finnish island of [[Suomenlinna]], where various events are prepared annually in honor of Kekri. The celebrations typically have included abundant feasts, with lamb roast traditionally being part of the menu.<ref>{{cite web|title=Kekri o el primo finlandés del Halloween|url=http://michanenfinlandia.com/2016/10/29/kekri-el-primo-finlandes-del-halloween/|website=Michan en Finlandia|accessdate=30 October 2016|language=Spanish}}</ref>
Although the Celtic-originated [[Halloween]] has gradually begun to penetrate into the Finnish autumn feast traditions from the [[United States]], Kekri has held its ground. In part due to the celebrations of Halloween having become increasingly commercial, many Finns prefer not to have it associated with Kekri or the [[All Saints' Day]] ([[Finnish language|Finnish]]: Pyhäinpäivä).
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Finnish culture]] [[Category:Autumn festivals]] [[Category:Autumn events in Finland]]
{{finland-stub}}

revision.text:
[[File:Right-wing populist parties in European national parliaments (June 2018).png|thumb|European national parliaments with representatives from right-wing populist parties in December 2017:
{{Farbindex|0080ff}} Right-wing populists represented in the parliament
{{Farbindex|004a95}} Right-wing populists involved in the government
{{Farbindex|002b55}} Right-wing populists appoint prime minister]] '''[[Nationalist]] parties in [[Europe]]''' have been on the rise since the early 2010s{{cite news|title=Throwing outsiders overboard: the rise of nationalism in Europe|url=http://rt.com/news/nationalism-rise-europe-crisis/|accessdate=2 July 2013|date=17 February 2011|agency=[[Russia Today]]}}{{cite news|title=EU president warns against rising nationalism in Europe|url=http://www.todayszaman.com/news-226877-eu-president-warns-against-rising-nationalism-in-europe.html|accessdate=2 July 2013|newspaper=[[Today's Zaman]]|date=11 November 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111217052315/http://www.todayszaman.com/news-226877-eu-president-warns-against-rising-nationalism-in-europe.html|archivedate=17 December 2011|df=}}{{cite news|title=Special report: The rise of the right in Europe|url=http://www.sbs.com.au/news/article/1773740/Special-report-The-rise-of-the-right-in-Europe|accessdate=2 July 2013|date=6 June 2013|agency=[[Special Broadcasting Service]]}}{{cite news|title=Rising European nationalism chills investors|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-505123_162-57419218/rising-european-nationalism-chills-investors/|accessdate=2 July 2013|newspaper=[[CBS News]]|date=23 April 2012}}{{cite news|title=Fascism and Ultranationalism on the Rise in Countries Across Europe|url=http://pulitzercenter.org/reporting/europe-greece-hungary-ultra-nationalism-fascism-xenophobia-new-dawn-anti-roma-anti-semitism|accessdate=2 July 2013|date=27 June 2013|agency=[[Pulitzer Center on Crisis Reporting]]}}{{cite news|title=Peter Popham: Rise of far right threatens to pollute politics across Europe|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/voices/commentators/peter-popham-rise-of-far-right-threatens-to-pollute-politics-across-europe-7718669.html|accessdate=2 July 2013|newspaper=[[The Independent]]|date=7 May 2012}} due to, according to some, [[austerity]] measures and immigration.{{cite news|last=Smith-Spark|first=Laura|title=Anger at austerity, immigration feeds far right's rise in Europe|url=http://www.cnn.com/2012/05/08/world/europe/europe-far-right-austerity|accessdate=25 June 2013|date=9 May 2012|agency=[[CNN]]}}{{cite news|title=Rise of anti-immigration, anti-EU far right parties in Europe causes concern|url=http://www.todayszaman.com/newsDetail_getNewsById.action?newsId=278834|accessdate=2 July 2013|newspaper=[[Today's Zaman]]|date=27 April 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120507104548/http://www.todayszaman.com/newsDetail_getNewsById.action?newsId=278834|archivedate=7 May 2012|df=}} [[Ruth Wodak]] stresses that the rise of populist parties across Europe has different reasons in different countries. In a March 2014 article she divided these parties into four groups: "parties [that] gain support via an ambivalent relationship with fascist and Nazi pasts" (e.g., in Austria, Hungary, Italy, Romania, and France), parties that "focus primarily on a perceived threat from Islam" (e.g., in the Netherlands, Denmark, Poland, Sweden, and Switzerland), parties that "restrict their propaganda to a perceived threat to their national identities from ethnic minorities" (e.g., in Hungary, Greece, Italy, and the United Kingdom) and parties that "endorse a fundamentalist Christian conservative-reactionary agenda" (e.g., in Poland, Romania and Bulgaria).{{cite news|last=Wodak|first=Ruth|title=Right wing populist parties on the rise|url=http://cyprus-mail.com/2014/03/04/right-wing-populist-parties-on-the-rise/|accessdate=8 March 2014|newspaper=[[Cyprus Mail]]|date=4 March 2014}} According to ''[[the Economist]]'', the main attraction of far-right parties in the [[Scandinavian countries]] is the national culture is under threat.{{cite news|title=Culture matters more|url=http://www.economist.com/node/21560294|accessdate=1 July 2013|newspaper=[[The Economist]]|date=11 August 2012}} ==Overview== Different parts of Europe have nationalist parties with different ideologies and goals. Most nationalist parties in Central and Western Europe are described as "[[Right-wing populism|right-wing populists]]".{{cite news|title=Continent of Fear: The Rise of Europe's Right-Wing Populists|url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/europe/continent-of-fear-the-rise-of-europe-s-right-wing-populists-a-719842.html|accessdate=1 July 2013|newspaper=[[Spiegel Online]]|date=28 September 2010}} According to Thomas Klau of the European Council on Foreign Relations "as antisemitism was a unifying factor for far-right parties in the 1910s, 20s and 30s, Islamophobia has become the unifying factor in the early decades of the 21st century."{{cite news|title=Far right on rise in Europe, says report|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/nov/06/far-right-rise-europe-report|accessdate=1 July 2013|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|date=6 November 2011|author=Walker, Peter|author2=Taylor, Matthew}} Many are Left Wing or Civic Nationalist Parties, which often advocate regionalism. Nationalist parties are the ruling party in the Republic of Macedonia the [[Internal Macedonian Revolutionary Organization – Democratic Party for Macedonian National Unity|VMRO-DPMNE]] is one of the two major parties in the country. [[Switzerland]] is also ruled by a nationalist party by the [[Swiss People's Party]]. In all other countries, nationalist parties are in opposition. In some countries, nationalist parties are major players in politics, such as [[France]]'s [[National Rally (France)|National Rally]], [[Finland]]'s [[True Finns]], [[Estonia]]'s [[Conservative People's Party of Estonia|Conservative People's Party]], [[Italy]]'s [[Lega Nord]], [[Austria]]'s [[Freedom Party of Austria]] [[Hungary]]'s [[Jobbik]], [[Turkey]]'s [[Nationalist Movement Party|MHP]], [[Greece]]'s [[Golden Dawn (political party)|Golden Dawn]] , [[Armenia]]'s [[Armenian Revolutionary Federation]], the [[United Kingdom]]'s [[UK Independence Party]], [[Poland]]'s [[Law and Justice]], [[Slovakia]]'s [[Slovak National Party]], [[Denmark]]'s [[Danish People's Party]] etc. Most, if not all, nationalist parties represented in the European Parliament are in the [[Europe of Freedom and Democracy]] group. ===Eastern Europe and the Caucasus === Nationalist parties in the Eastern European states differ from the ones in Western Europe mostly by the fact that there is virtually no immigration into these countries.{{Citation needed|date = February 2016}} Governments in Belarus and Azerbaijan are often considered totalitarian and elections in these countries have been described unfair and not free and thus the parliaments are effectively controlled by the ruling party.{{Citation needed|date = February 2016}} ==Recent Developments== === Slovenian Parliamentary Elections, 3 June 2018 === Slovenia held its [[Slovenian parliamentary election, 2018|Parliamentary Elections]] to the [[National Assembly (Slovenia)|National Assembly of Slovenia]] on the 3rd June, 2018, where 90 members were elected. The [[Slovenian National Party]] and [[Slovenian Democratic Party]] are the country's two nationalist, far-rightist parties and both gained seats under this election. The Slovenian Democratic Party is the largest party by seats in the National Assembly with 25, while the Slovenian National Party is the smallest party with 4.{{Cite web|url=http://volitve.gov.si/dz2018/#/rezultati|title=http://volitve.gov.si/dz2018/#/rezultati|last=d.o.o.|first=SRC|website=volitve.gov.si|access-date=2018-06-04}} Thus 29 seats are held by nationalist parties, up 8 seats from the [[Slovenian parliamentary election, 2014|last elections in 2014]]. A new Government has yet to be formed, though in any case there will be a strong nationalist sentiment in the Assembly. === United Kingdom Local Elections, 3 May 2018 === The United Kingdom held [[United Kingdom local elections, 2018|Local Elections]] on the 3rd of May for around a quarter of [[Local government in England|local government]] seats in England. The [[United Kingdom Independence Party]] lost 103 seats during this round of elections, showing a decline in support for local government-level nationalism in the country after the [[Brexit]] referendum of 2016. === Hungarian Parliamentary Elections, 8 April 2018 === Hungary held its [[Hungarian parliamentary election, 2018|General Parliamentary Elections]] on the 8th April 2018, where 199 seats in the [[National Assembly (Hungary)|National Assembly of Hungary]] were filled. Two nationalist parties, all far-right, emerged with seats in the new Assembly, with the new Prime Minister, [[Viktor Orbán|Viktor Orban]], being from the [[Fidesz]]-[[Christian Democratic People's Party (Hungary)|Christian Democratic People's Party]]. His party gained 133 seats, while the [[Jobbik|Jobbik-Movement for a Better Hungary Party]] gained 26 seats. This put 159 out of 199 seats in the Hungarian National Assembly under the control of nationalist parties, up 3 seats from the [[Hungarian parliamentary election, 2014|last election in 2014]]. ===Italian General Elections, 4 March 2018=== Italy held its [[Italian general election, 2018|General Elections on the 4th March, 2018]], where 630 Deputies were elected to the Lower House and 315 Senators to the Upper House of the Italian Parliament. Italy's largest far-right party, the [[Lega Nord]] or "League" secured 125 seats in the [[Chamber of Deputies (Italy)|Chamber of Deputies]] ([[Lower house|Lower House]]) and 58 seats in the [[Senate of the Republic (Italy)|Senate]] ([[Upper house|Upper House]]). The [[Brothers of Italy]], another nationalist party, gained 32 seats in the Chamber of Deputies and 18 seats in the Senate. Italy's [[Five Star Movement]] (M5S) have also been labelled as being in the far-right. Gaining 222 seats in the Chamber of Deputies and 109 seats in the Senate, that would make M5S the largest far-right group in Italy, though arguably, they are not officially a far-right group.{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/ng-interactive/2018/mar/05/italian-elections-2018-full-results-renzi-berlusconi|title=Italian elections 2018 - full results|last=Henley|first=Jon|work=The Guardian|access-date=2018-06-04|last2=Voce|first2=Antonio|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.thelocal.it/20180206/political-election-understanding-italys-five-star-movement-m5s-di-maio-grillo|title=Political cheat sheet: Understanding Italy's Five Star Movement|date=2018-02-06|access-date=2018-06-04|language=en}} The current government, formed with Prime Minister [[Giuseppe Conte]] as its head, supported by parties including the League, the Brothers of Italy and M5S, which together contribute 379 seats in the Chamber of Deputies and 185 seats in the Senate. A large portion of the Italian Government is therefore far-rightist and/or nationalist. Between them, the three parties went up by 140 seats in the Chamber of Deputies and by 20 seats in the Senate compared to the [[Italian general election, 2013|last election in 2013]]. ==List== *{{legend inline|#FFFF00|the governing party}} *{{legend inline|#FFAF3E|giving parliamentary support}} ===National=== {| class="wikitable sortable" !
