Act}} | longtitle = An Act to regulate the transportation for dumping, and the dumping, of material into ocean waters, and for other purposes. | colloquialacronym = MPRSA, ODA | nickname = Ocean Dumping Act | enacted by = 92nd | effective date = October 23, 1972 | public law url = http://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/STATUTE-86/pdf/STATUTE-86-Pg1052.pdf | cite public law = 92-532 | cite statutes at large = {{usstat|86|1052}} | acts amended = | acts repealed = | title amended = {{unbulleted list|[[Title 16 of the United States Code|16 U.S.C.: Conservation]]|[[Title 33 of the United States Code|33 U.S.C.: Navigable Waters]]}} | sections created = {{unbulleted list|{{Usc-title-chap|16|32}} §§ 1431 - 1445.|{{Usc-title-chap|16|32a}} §§ 1447 - 1447f.|{{Usc-title-chap|33|27}} §§ 1401 - 1445.|{{Usc-title-chap|33|41}} §§ 2801 - 2805.}} | sections amended = | leghisturl = | introducedin = House | introducedbill = {{USBill|92|H.R.|9727}} | introducedby = <!--sponsor(s)--> | introduceddate = | committees = | passedbody1 = | passeddate1 = | passedvote1 = | passedbody2 = | passedas2 = <!-- used if the second body changes the name of the legislation --> | passeddate2 = | passedvote2 = | conferencedate = | passedbody3 = | passeddate3 = | passedvote3 = | agreedbody3 = <!-- used when the other body agrees without going into committee --> | agreeddate3 = <!-- used when the other body agrees without going into committee --> | agreedvote3 = <!-- used when the other body agrees without going into committee --> | agreedbody4 = <!-- used if agreedbody3 further amends legislation --> | agreeddate4 = <!-- used if agreedbody3 further amends legislation --> | agreedvote4 = <!-- used if agreedbody3 further amends legislation --> | passedbody4 = | passeddate4 = | passedvote4 = | signedpresident = [[Richard Nixon]] | signeddate = October 23, 1972 | unsignedpresident = <!-- used when passed without presidential signing --> | unsigneddate = <!-- used when passed without presidential signing --> | vetoedpresident = <!-- used when passed by overriding presidential veto --> | vetoeddate = <!-- used when passed by overriding presidential veto --> | overriddenbody1 = <!-- used when passed by overriding presidential veto --> | overriddendate1 = <!-- used when passed by overriding presidential veto --> | overriddenvote1 = <!-- used when passed by overriding presidential veto --> | overriddenbody2 = <!-- used when passed by overriding presidential veto --> | overriddendate2 = <!-- used when passed by overriding presidential veto --> | overriddenvote2 = <!-- used when passed by overriding presidential veto --> | amendments = {{unbulleted list|{{USStatute|100|627|102|3213|1988|11|07}}|{{USStatute|100|688|102|4139|1988|11|18}}}} | SCOTUS cases = }} '''Marine Protection, Research and Sanctuaries Act of 1972 (MPRSA)''' or '''Ocean Dumping Act''' is one of several key [[environmental law]]s passed by the [[United States Congress|US Congress]] in 1972.<ref>Marine Protection, Research and Sanctuaries Act of 1972, {{USStatute|92|532|86|1052|1972|10|23}}. Full statute is at 86 Stat. 1052 and 1061. Titles I and II are codified at {{USC|33|1401-1445}}. Title III is codified at {{USC|16|1431-1445}}.</ref><ref>U.S. Senate. {{cite journal|title=Marine Protection, Research and Sanctuaries Act of 1972 |url=http://epw.senate.gov/mprsa72.pdf}} (Full text)</ref> The Act has two essential aims: to regulate intentional ocean disposal of materials, and to authorize any related research.<ref name="Ocean Dumping Act a Summary of the Law">Claudia Copeland. Cong. Bill. Washington, D.C.: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress, 1999.{{full citation needed|date=November 2012}}</ref> While the MPRSA regulates the ocean dumping of waste and provides for a research program on ocean dumping, it also provides for the designation and regulation of marine sanctuaries.<ref name="The Office of Health, Safety and Security">The Office of Health, Safety and Security - Home. Web. 09 Nov. 2011.{{full citation needed|date=November 2012}}</ref> The act regulates the ocean dumping of all material beyond the territorial limit ({{convert|3|mi|km}} from shore) and prevents or strictly limits dumping material that "would adversely affect human health, welfare, or amenities, or the marine environment, ecological systems, or economic potentialities".<ref name="The Office of Health, Safety and Security"/> The MPRSA authorized the [[U.S. Environmental Protection Agency|Environmental Protection Agency]] (EPA) to regulate ocean dumping of materials including, but not limited to, [[industrial waste]], [[sewage sludge]], [[biological agents]], [[Radionuclide|radioactive agents]], NBC ([[nuclear warfare|nuclear]], [[biological warfare|biological]], and [[chemical warfare|chemical]]), garbage, chemicals, and biological and laboratory, as well as other wastes, into the territorial waters of the United States through a permit program. The EPA can issue permits for dumping of materials other than dredge spoils if the agency determines, through a full public notice and process, that the discharge will not unreasonably degrade or endanger human health or welfare or the marine environment.<ref name="Other Laws to Protect Your Watershed">Other Laws to Protect Your Watershed. River Network. Web. 09 Nov. 2011.</ref> The law also has provisions related to creating marine sanctuaries, conducting ocean disposal research and monitoring coastal water quality.<ref name="Other Laws to Protect Your Watershed"/>
==Ocean Dumping Code== {{Gallery |title=Ocean Dumping |width=160 |height=170 |lines=4 |align=center ||alt1=ocean dumping, barrels being dump into the ocean|Barrels being dump in the ocean.<ref name="ocean dump.">[http://www.wix.com/sandylish/ocean-dumping "Ocean Dumping" ]</ref> ||alt2=ocean dumping, garbage|The R.C. Mohawk - victim of 63 years of sludge dumping<ref name="scuba diving">[http://njscuba.net/biology/misc_bottom.html#dumps Offshore Dumping Grounds], {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090608014445/http://njscuba.net/biology/misc_bottom.html |date=2009-06-08 }} at NJ scuba diving website, accessed 11/11/07.</ref> ||alt3=ocean dumping, garbage|Garbage barge.<ref name="Ocean Dumping Before the Marine Protection Research and Sanctuaries Act (MPRSA).">[http://water.epa.gov/type/oceb/mprsa_before.cfm. '''EPA''' "Ocean Dumping Before the Marine Protection Research and Sanctuaries Act (MPRSA)." EPA Journal. March 06, 2012 ]</ref> ||alt4=ocean dumping, dump sludge|Sludge being dump into the ocean.<ref name="Ocean Dumping Before the Marine Protection Research and Sanctuaries Act (MPRSA)."/> }}

Major U.S. Code Sections of the Marine Protection, Research, and Sanctuaries Act (codified as 33 U.S.C. 1401-1445, 16 U.S.C. 1431-1447f, 33 U.S.C. 2801-2805).<ref name="Ocean Dumping Act: A Summary of the Law.">[http://www.gc.noaa.gov/documents/gcil_crs_oda.pdf Copelan, Claudia. Ocean Dumping Act: A Summary of the Law. Web. May 9, 2012.]</ref>''' ! scope="col" | ! scope="col" | Section Title ! scope="col" | Ocean Dumping Act |- | '''33 U.S.C''' |- |1401 || Congressional findings, declaration of policy || Sec. 2 |- |1401 || Definitions || Sec. 3 |- |'''Title I - Permit Program''' |- |1411 || Prohibited acts || Sec. 101 |- |1412 || Environmental Protection Agency permits || Sec. 102 |- |1413 || Corps of Engineers permits || Sec. 103 |- |1414 || Permit conditions || Sec. 104 |- |1414a || Special provisions regarding certain dumping sites || Sec. 104A |- |1414b || Ocean dumping of sewage sludge and industrial waste || Sec. 104B |- |1414c || Prohibition on disposal of sewage sludge at landfills on Staten Island || Sec. 104C |- |1415 || Penalties || Sec. 105 |- |1416 || Relationship to other laws || Sec. 106 |- |1417 || Enforcement || Sec. 107 |- |1418 || Regulations || Sec. 108 |- |1419 || International cooperation || Sec. 109 |- |1420 || Authorization of appropriations || Sec. 111 |- |1421 || Annual report to Congress || Sec. 112 |- |'''Title II - Research Programs''' |- |1441 || Monitoring and research programs || Sec. 201 |- |1442 || Research on long-term effects || Sec. 202 |- |1443 || Research program - ocean dumping and other methods || Sec. 203 |- |1444 || Annual reports || Sec. 204 |- |1445 || Authorization of appropriations || Sec. 205 |- |'''Title III - Marine Sanctuaries''' |- |'''Title IV - Regional Marine Research Programs''' |- |'''16 U.S.C.''' |- |1447 || Purposes || Sec. 401 |- |1447a || Definitions || Sec. 402 |- |1447b || Regional marine research boards || Sec. 403 |- |1447c || Regional research plans || Sec. 404 |- |1447d || Research grant program || Sec. 405 |- |1447e || Report on research program || Sec. 406 |- |1447f || Authorization of appropriations || Sec. 407 |- |'''Title V - National Coastal Monitoring System''' |- |'''33 U.S.C.''' |- |2801 || Purposes || Sec. 501 |- |2802 || Definitions || Sec. 502 |- |2803 || Comprehensive coastal water quality monitoring program || Sec. 503 |- |2804 || Report to Congress || Sec. 504 |- |2805 || Authorization of appropriations || Sec. 505 |- |}
==Responsible agencies== There are four federal agencies that share responsibilities under the Ocean Dumping Act:<ref name="Ocean Dumping Act: A Summary of the Law."/>
*[[United States Environmental Protection Agency|U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA)]] *[[United States Army Corps of Engineers|U.S. Army Corps of Engineers]] *[[National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration|National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration(NOAA)]] *[[United States Coast Guard|U.S. Coast Guard]]
The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) is the primary agency that is in charge of regulating the disposal of all substances that are disposed in the ocean; this agency also authorize the research and demonstration of activities that have to do with phasing out sewage and industrial waste disposing.<ref name="Ocean Dumping Act: A Summary of the Law."/> The U.S. Army Corps of Engineers agency is in charge of dredged spoils.<ref name="Ocean Dumping Act: A Summary of the Law."/> The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) is in charge of the research on the changes of the marine environment that are caused by humans.<ref name="Ocean Dumping Act: A Summary of the Law."/> The U.S. Coast Guard is in charge of the surveillance of ocean dumping.<ref name="Ocean Dumping Act: A Summary of the Law."/>
The NOAA National Marine Sanctuary program manages a network of underwater areas that are protected by the US. These special bodies of water, like oceans and lakes, are protected by Congress to keep natural and cultural resources while allowing people to enjoy the waters. The Marine Protection, Research, Sanctuaries Act gives way for a national network of marine sanctuaries that are administered by NOAA. The NOAA was created in 1970 after an oil spill 30 miles of the coast of California released 235,000 gallons of crude oil into the ocean. As time passes and technology advances, the NOAA has added sanctuaries all over the US. Three sites followed from 1992, with Congress designating [[Stellwagen Bank National Marine Sanctuary]] in Massachusetts and [[Monterey Bay National Marine Sanctuary]] in California.
==Title I - Permit Program==
Title I of the MPRSA prohibits all ocean dumping, except that allowed by permits issued by the EPA Administrator pursuant to Section 102 of the MPRSA, in any ocean waters under U.S. jurisdiction, by any U.S. vessel, or by any vessel sailing from a U.S. port.<ref name="Ocean Dumping Act a Summary of the Law"/><ref name="Marine Protection, Research, and Sanctuaries Act, United States">Marine Protection, Research, and Sanctuaries Act, United States. Encyclopedia of Earth. Web. 09 Nov. 2011.</ref> EPA designates sites for ocean dumping and specifies in each permit where the material is to be disposed.<ref name="Ocean Dumping Act a Summary of the Law"/><ref name="Marine Protection, Research, and Sanctuaries Act, United States"/>
In 1973, the EPA permitted two interim chemical disposal sites in the Gulf of Mexico, as described in the report, Assessing Potential Ocean Pollutants, published by the National Academy of Sciences (NAS, 1975) [https://books.google.com/books/about/Assessing_Potential_Ocean_Pollutants.html?id=eicQOgkswusC https://books.google.com/books/about/Assessing_Potential_Ocean_Pollutants.html?id=eicQOgkswusC]. At Site A, uncontained wastes were discharged through a submerged pipe into the turbulent wake of a barge. At Site B, waste materials were placed in barrels before discharge. Chemical wastes discharged at these sites reportedly had various concentrations of chlorinated hydrocarbons, calcium and sodium metals, formaldehyde, cyanide and other metals (i.e. antimony, mercury, arsenic, zinc, manganese, and iron). Seven permits issued by the EPA in 1973 for the period of May 1 to November 1 allowed for the disposal of 84,500 tons of uncontained waste at Site A and 208,500 waste barrels at Site B, of which 55,000 barrels contained chlorinated hydrocarbons. By July 1973, four companies with plants at 7 locations were using Sites A and B (NAS, 1975).
Nearly all of the ocean dumping that takes place today is dredged materials at the hands of the Corps of Engineers and due to the fact that they are the entity primarily responsible for the dredging, they issue permits for ocean dumping of such materials.<ref name="Ocean Dumping Act a Summary of the Law"/><ref name="Marine Protection, Research, and Sanctuaries Act, United States"/> The dredged materials are sediments removed from the bottom of water bodies, but before they are dumped in the ocean, they must be evaluated to ensure that they are not harmful to human health or to the marine environment.<ref name="Ocean Dumping Act a Summary of the Law"/><ref name="Marine Protection, Research, and Sanctuaries Act, United States"/>
The basic objective of the permit program is to "prevent or strictly limit the dumping into [[ocean]] waters of any material that would adversely affect human health, welfare, or amenities, or the [[marine environment]], [[ecosystem]]s, or economic potentialities."<ref name="ReferenceA">MPRSA sec. 2(b), {{USC|33|1401(b)}}.</ref> The [[United States Secretary of the Army|Secretary of the Army]] (through the [[United States Army Corps of Engineers|Corps of Engineers]]) is authorized to issue permits for dredged material disposal, and EPA is authorized to designate appropriate dump sites.
Dumping restrictions were enacted for both U.S. flag vessels and materials transported from a location outside the U.S. With respect to the latter category, dumping was prohibited within the U.S. territorial sea and the U.S. contiguous zone. A specific dumping prohibition was included for radiological, chemical and biological warfare agents, high-level [[radioactive waste]] and [[medical waste]]s. Restrictions have since been placed on dumping activities in the [[New York Bight]] Apex, and sewage sludge dumping at the "106-Mile Site" offshore of New Jersey ended in 1992.<ref>U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) and National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. Washington, DC (1995). [http://www.epa.gov/history/topics/mprsa/Monitoring,ResearchandSurveillanceofthe106MileDeepw.pdf "Monitoring, Research, and Surveillance of the 106-Mile Deepwater Municipal Dump Site and Environs.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110205085512/http://www.epa.gov/history/topics/mprsa/Monitoring%2CResearchandSurveillanceofthe106MileDeepw.pdf |date=2011-02-05 }} ''Report to Congress.'' Document no. EPA-842-R-95-001. p. iii.</ref>
In order for anyone to dump on US waters, they must follow certain laws. Public Law 97-424, enacted in 1983, placed a 2-year prohibition on ocean dumping of any low-level radioactive waste. Public Law 100-688 terminated the dumping of sewage sludge and waste from industrial companies (commencing with the 270th day after November 18, 1988) under certain conditions.<ref name="ReferenceA"/> After December 31, 1991, it was prohibited to dump any type of sewage sludge and industrial waste. This law gives EPA the authority to issue emergency permits for the dumping of industrial waste into ocean waters if an unacceptable human health risk exists and no other alternative is available.
<ref name="ReferenceA"/> Statutes authorizing appropriations to implement Title I were enacted annually through 1977 and, thereafter, in 1980, 1981, and 1988. The 1988 amendments authorized appropriations of $12 million for Title I for each of Fiscal Years 1989 through 1991.
==Title II - Research Programs== Title II of the Act authorizes the [[Secretary of Commerce]] (through the [[National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration]] (NOAA)) to coordinate a research and monitoring program with the EPA and the [[United States Coast Guard]]. The NOAA conducts general research on ocean resources and is responsible for research on the effects of ocean dumping, pollution, overfishing, and other issues caused by humans that cause changes in the marine ecosystem.<ref name="Ocean Dumping Act a Summary of the Law"/><ref name="Marine Protection, Research, and Sanctuaries Act, United States"/> The EPA's research is related to the phasing out of ocean disposal activities and its role includes conducting research, surveys, investigations, experiments, training, demonstrations, and studies to aid in their search for dumping alternatives.<ref name="Ocean Dumping Act a Summary of the Law"/><ref name="Ocean Dumping Act a Summary of the Law"/>
<ref name="Marine Protection, Research, and Sanctuaries Act, United States"/> This program is designed as a long-term research program to study the "possible long-range effects of pollution, overfishing, and man-induced changes of [[ocean]] [[ecosystem]]s" and to conduct the research required to find dumping alternatives and to consider, in cooperation with other federal agencies, the feasibility of regional management plans for waste disposal in coastal areas. Congressional reports are required annually.
Statutes providing authority for appropriations were enacted in 1972, 1975, 1976, 1977, 1980, 1986 and 1988. Public Law 100-627 authorized appropriations of $13.5 million for Title II for Fiscal Year 1989, and $14.5 million for Fiscal Year 1990.
==Title III - Marine Sanctuaries==
Title III allows the Secretary of Commerce to designate discrete areas as National Marine Sanctuaries after conferring with the heads of involved federal agencies and state and local governments, as appropriate.<ref name="The Office of Health, Safety and Security"/><ref name="NOAA National Marine Sanctuaries">NOAA National Marine Sanctuaries: Oceans, Marine Life, Shipwrecks, Diving, Whales, Voyage to Discovery. Web. 09 Nov. 2011.</ref> The establishment of these sanctuaries is important in helping to promote comprehensive management of their special conservation, recreational, ecological, historical, research, educational, or aesthetic resources.<ref name="The Office of Health, Safety and Security"/> The importance and primary objective of a sanctuary is to protect its features and allow the ocean to be used in a natural and sustainable way.<ref name="The Office of Health, Safety and Security"/> Sanctuaries provide a safe haven for endangered species, or those close to extinction, while also serving educational purposes for students and researchers alike to promote understanding and stewardship of our oceans.<ref name="The Office of Health, Safety and Security"/>
Public Law 96-332 provides that any marine sanctuary designation will not be effective if the Governor of an affected state finds it unacceptable, or if Congress form a concurrent of dissproval (must occur within 60 days). The Secretary of Commerce is authorized to withdraw the designation after any such State or Congressional disapproval. If the designation is not withdrawn, only the portion certified as acceptable can take effect.
==Title IV - Regional Marine Research Programs==
Title IV of the MPRSA established nine regional marine research boards for the purpose of developing comprehensive marine research plans, considering water quality and ecosystem conditions and research and monitoring priorities and objectives in each region.<ref name="Ocean Dumping Act a Summary of the Law"/> The plans, after approval by the NOAA and EPA, are to guide NOAA in awarding research grants funds under this title of the act.<ref name="Ocean Dumping Act a Summary of the Law"/><ref name="Ocean Dumping Act a Summary of the Law"/> The Regional Marine Research Act was enacted in recognition of the value of the Nation's coastal marine waters and the need for regional research to safeguard their quality and health. The main focus of this program is to establish regional marine research programs around the country and to provide sustained federal funding for planned research within each region.<ref name="Ocean Dumping Act a Summary of the Law"/> Five Major Sections of the [[Gulf of Maine Regional Marine Research Program]]: 1. An overview of marine environmental quality in the region. 2. An inventory of current research activities. 3. A statement of the research needs and priorities within the context of a 10-year goal. 4. An assessment of how the plan will incorporate existing research and management in the region 5. A description and schedule of the research objectives for the region during the 4-year period covered by the plan.
==Title V - National Coastal Monitoring System==
Title V launched a national coastal water quality monitoring program that directs the EPA and NOAA together to implement a long-term program to collect and analyze scientific data on the environmental quality of coastal ecosystems, including ambient water quality, health and quality of living resources, sources of environmental degradation, and data on trends.<ref name="Ocean Dumping Act a Summary of the Law"/> Results of these actions are used to provide the information required to devise and execute effective programs under the Clean Water Act and Coastal Zone Management Act.<ref name="Ocean Dumping Act a Summary of the Law"/>
==Amendments==
In 1977, Congress amended the Act to require that dumping of municipal sewage sludge or industrial wastes, which unreasonably degrade the environment, to cease by December 1981.<ref name="Marine Protection, Research, and Sanctuaries Act, United States"/> Because that deadline was not achieved, amendments were passed in 1988 that extended the deadline to December 1991.<ref name="Marine Protection, Research, and Sanctuaries Act, United States"/> In 1986 amendments, Congress directed that ocean disposal of all wastes end at the traditional 12-mile site off the New York/New Jersey coast and that they be moved to a new site 106 miles offshore.<ref name="Marine Protection, Research, and Sanctuaries Act, United States"/> Congress amended the Act again in 1992, giving permission to states to adopt ocean dumping standards more stringent than federal standards and to require that permits conform with long-term management plans for designated dumpsites.<ref name="Marine Protection, Research, and Sanctuaries Act, United States"/> This amendment was put into place to ensure that permitted activities are consistent with expected uses of the site.<ref name="Marine Protection, Research, and Sanctuaries Act, United States"/>
{| class="wikitable" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto;" |+ '''Table 2. Ocean Dumping Act and Amendments (codified as 33 U.S.C. 1401-1445, 16 U.S.C. 1431-1447f, 33 U.S.C. 2801-2805).<ref name="Ocean Dumping Act: A Summary of the Law."/>''' ! scope="col" | Year ! scope="col" | Act ! scope="col" | Public Law Number |- | 1972 || Marine Protection, Research, and Sanctuaries Act || P.L. 92-532 |- ||1974 || London Dumping Convention Implementation || P.L. 93-254 |- |1977 || Authorization of appropriations || P.L. 95-153 |- |1980 || Authorization of appropriations || P.L. 96-381 |- |1980 || Authorization of appropriations || P.L. 96-572 |- |1982 || Surface Transportation Assistance Act || P.L. 97-424 |- |1986 || Budget Reconciliation || P.L. 99-272, §§6061-6065 |- |1986 || Water Resources Development Act || P.L. 99-662, §§21 1, 728, 1172 |- |1987 || Water Quality Act of 1987 || P.L. 100-4, §508 |- |1988 || Ocean dumping research amendments || P.L. 100-627, title I |- |1988 || Ocean Dumping Ban Act || P.L. 100-688, title I |- |1988 || U.S. Public Vessel Medical Waste Anti-Dumping || P.L. 100-688, title III Act of 1988 |- |1990 || Regional marine research centers || P.L. 101-593, title III |- |1992 || National Coastal Monitoring Act || P.L. 102-567, title V |- |1992 || Water Resource Development Act || P.L. 102-580, §§504-510 |- |}
==Enforcement==
The violation of a permit or permit requirement carries a civil penalty of not more than $75,000 per violation that is assessed by the EPA.<ref name="Ocean Dumping Act a Summary of the Law"/><ref name="Marine Protection, Research, and Sanctuaries Act, United States"/> The organization is also authorized to assess criminal penalties that carry fines up to $250,000, 5 years in prison, or both for violations of the act.<ref name="Ocean Dumping Act a Summary of the Law"/><ref name="Marine Protection, Research, and Sanctuaries Act, United States"/> Additionally, fines are assessed for ocean dumping of medical wastes that carry the same penalties previously listed.<ref name="Ocean Dumping Act a Summary of the Law"/><ref name="Marine Protection, Research, and Sanctuaries Act, United States"/> Like many other federal environmental laws, the Ocean Dumping Act allows individuals to bring a citizen suit in U.S. district court against any person, including the United States, for violation of a permit or other prohibition, limitation, or criterion issued under title I of the Act.<ref name="Ocean Dumping Act a Summary of the Law"/><ref name="Marine Protection, Research, and Sanctuaries Act, United States"/>
Under certain circumstances, each of the states is permitted to regulate ocean dumping in waters within their own jurisdiction.<ref name="Ocean Dumping Act: A Summary of the Law."/> The Ocean Dumping Act requires that the EPA Administrator applies the standards and criteria binding upon the United States that are stated in the 1972 Convention on the Prevention of Marine Pollution by Dumping of Wastes and Other Matters.<ref name="Ocean Dumping Act: A Summary of the Law."/> During this convention, more than 85 countries agreed in the prohibition of dumping in the ocean the next elements: mercury, cadmium and other substances such as DDT and PCBs, solid wastes and persistent plastics, oil, high-level radioactive wastes, and chemical and biological warfare agents; and requires special permits for other heavy metals, cyanides and fluorides, and medium- and low-level radioactive wastes.<ref name="Ocean Dumping Act: A Summary of the Law."/>

{{small|(1998-2004)}} }} | slogan = | country = | language = | broadcast area = | affiliates = | headquarters = | former names = [[Music Box (TV channel)|Music Box]] (1984-1987)
Super Channel (1987-1993)
NBC Super Channel (1993-1996) | replaced names = | replaced by names = [[GIGA Television|GIGA]]
[[Das Vierte]]
[[National Geographic Channel (disambiguation)|National Geographic Channel]] | sister names = [[CNBC Europe]] | timeshift names = | web = | terr serv 1 = | terr chan 1 = | sat serv 1 = | sat chan 1 = | cable serv 1 = | cable chan 1 = | sat radio serv 1 = | sat radio chan 1 = | iptv serv 1 = | iptv chan 1 = | online serv 1 = | online chan 1 = | 3gmobile serv 1 = }} '''NBC Europe''' (formerly '''Super Channel''' and '''NBC Super Channel''') was a [[satellite television]] [[Television channel|channel]] based in the [[United Kingdom]] that broadcast across [[Europe]]. It was picked up by various European [[cable television]] networks. ==Super Channel== [[File:Superchannel1987.jpg|thumb|left|Super Channel 1987-1993]] Launched on 30 January 1987, replacing 24-hour music channel [[Music Box (TV channel)|Music Box]], Super Channel was co-owned by all but one of the [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]] companies at the time in the [[United Kingdom]].{{cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071026144848/http://www.broadbandtvnews.com/archive_uk/091205.html|title=Broadband TV News - UK - Archive December 9, 2005|date=26 October 2007|publisher=}} [[Virgin Group]] had a majority stake in Music Box (60%) and would own 15% of the equity with the rest being split between ITV franchise holders including [[ITV Granada|Granada]], [[ITV Yorkshire|Yorkshire]], [[London Weekend Television|LWT]], [[ITV Central|Central]], [[ITV Anglia|Anglia]], [[ITV Tyne Tees|Tyne Tees]], [[UTV (TV channel)|Ulster]], [[Grampian Television|Grampian]], [[Scottish Television|Scottish]], and [[ITV Border|Border Television]]. [[Thames Television]] was the only one of the ITV contractors not to participate.[https://books.google.com/books?id=SoUAAwAAQBAJ&lpg=PA25&vq=Super%20Channel&pg=PA25#v=onepage&q&f=false ''Transnational Television in Europe: Reconfiguring Global Communications Networks''], Jean K. Chalaby, I.B.Tauris, page 25 It competed with Sky Channel, forerunner of [[Sky1]], which was the only other major pan-European satellite-channel around at the time. Unlike Sky Channel, Super Channel's [[television syndication|syndicated]] output was less [[United States|American]] and more [[Europe]]an. Many of the programmes were what it called the "Best of British", sourced from ITV or the [[BBC]], while [[ITN]] produced news bulletins (''see also [[ITN World News]]''). It also broadcast syndicated non-British European programmes such as the [[Netherlands|Dutch]] [[sitcom]] ''[[Zeg 'ns Aaa]]'' (with [[English language|English]] [[subtitles]]). Super Channel fared poorly, due to UK programming seen as unsuitable for European audiences, such as drama being seen as "too violent" or "too realistic",[https://books.google.com/books?id=xv4cAQAAMAAJ&q=%22Super+Channel%22&dq=%22Super+Channel%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwihroaI99LUAhUHAsAKHWooCOkQ6AEILDAB ''Media Information Australia''], Australian Film and Television School, 1990, age 80-, 83, 1990, Issues 55-58 as well as a dispute with the British actors unions who demanded additional fees for viewing by European audiences which meant that it could no longer offer the 'Best of British to a European audience'. Within a year, the ITV companies sold the channel to the [[Italy|Italian]] Marcucci family, owners of [[Videomusic]], the first music channel in Italy, with a minority stake being held by [[Richard Branson]]'s [[Virgin plc]], and the programming changed from British to pan-European, although it continued carrying ITN's World News bulletins. At the beginning Super Channel was based in the heart of London, 19-22 Rathbone Place, London W1P 1DF, in the same building as [[Music Box (TV channel)|Music Box]]; the building would later become the home of [[CNN International]] until 2007. For a number of months the channel's transmission facilities were provided by Molinare at Fouberts Place, London W1 until the Marcucci family acquired Melrose House, 14 Lanark Square, in [[Limeharbour]] (London) where it set up a state of the art transmission facility. In 1996 the channel (along with its sister channel [[CNBC Europe]]) was transmitted from the GE building in Hammersmith, London. The transmission suite used cutting edge (at the time) Pro-Bel COMPASS and MAPP automation, and Profile video servers for all commercials and promotions. Programmes continued to be played from tape, however. ==NBC steps in== [[File:NBC Super Channel 1994.jpg|thumb|NBC Super Channel 1993-1996]] In 1993, the station was having financial difficulties, and was taken over by the [[United States|American]] company [[General Electric]], then-parent of the [[NBC]] [[television network]], and became '''NBC Super Channel'''.{{cite web|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9F0CE1DE1238F931A35753C1A965958260|title=COMPANY NEWS; NBC to Control Super Channel|first=|last=Reuters|publisher=}} In 1996, the channel was renamed '''NBC Europe''', but was, from then on, almost always referred to as simply "NBC" on the air. Most of NBC Europe's prime time programming was produced in Europe, but after 10 pm [[Central European Time]] on weekday evenings, the channel aired ''[[The Tonight Show]]'', ''[[Late Night with Conan O'Brien]]'', and ''[[Later (talk show)|Later]]'', hence its slogan "Where the Stars Come Out at Night." Most [[NBC News]] programs were broadcast on NBC Europe, including ''[[Dateline NBC]]'', ''[[Time and Again (TV series)|Time and Again]]'' and ''[[NBC Nightly News]]'', which was aired live. ''[[Today (NBC program)|The Today Show]]'' was also initially shown live in the afternoons, but was later broadcast the following morning instead, by which time it was more than half a day old. That meant that all news portions had to be replaced with European updates produced by [[ITN]] in London. [[ITN]] also supplied the network with the main European newscasts before and after the [[General Electric|GE]] takeover. The European weather was produced by the [[BBC]] at first, but was later taken over by [[NBC]] in the U.S. NBC Europe carried virtually no [[prime time]] fiction entertainment programs shown on [[NBC]] in the US, because they were usually owned and distributed by other studios under the [[fin-syn]] rules (which did not apply for Europe). [[NBC]] would have had to buy the rights for each country in order to show them on NBC Europe, which would have been too expensive. Even for shows that [[Universal Television|NBC Studios]] owned itself, it was generally more financially viable to sell the rights country by country either to broadcast or cable/satellite channels than to air them on NBC Europe. The most notable exceptions to this rule were brief runs of ''[[Profiler (TV series)|Profiler]]'' and ''[[The Pretender (TV series)|The Pretender]]'', as well as short-lived US sitcoms ''[[Union Square (television)|Union Square]]'' and ''[[Mr. Rhodes]]''. That is widely considered to be one of the main reasons why NBC Europe was ultimately not a success. == NBC Europe as a German network == [[File:GIGA real.jpg|thumb|Studio of news programme "GIGA Real"]] NBC Europe stopped broadcasting to most of Europe in 1998, when the DFA (Deutsche Fernsehnachrichten Agentur) took it over and moved it to [[Düsseldorf]]. Most of the satellite feeds of NBC Europe became either National Geographic or CNBC. NBC Europe continued to operate on the German cable TV, fed by one digital satellite link from Eutelsat II-F1 (later Hotbird 5). In November 1998 the first German programming started airing. Programming was assembled with content from [[GIGA Television|GIGA]] and [[CNBC Europe]], as well as other shows. In 2004, [[NBC Universal]] took over the DFA and consequently NBC Europe. On 29 September 2005 NBC Europe was split into [[GIGA Television|GIGA]] and the new channel [[Das Vierte]]. NBC Europe was replaced by Das Vierte. In fact Das Vierte is still broadcasting with the licence of NBC Europe on [[Cable television|cable TV]]; on satellite, IPTV and digital cable it is a new channel. Das Vierte broadcasts a special version on cable TV, including [[CNBC Europe]], and from 29 September 2005 to 31 March 2006, also [[GIGA Television|GIGA]]. This is necessary to keep the licence and the cable channel. Image:NBC Europe 01.jpg|Ident ==Programming== Due to limitations on the amount of entertainment programming on the network, ''NBC Europe'' aired a number of original programming in tandem with [[United States|American]] programming that had not been aired in Europe beforehand. These programmes include: {{col-begin}} {{col-2}} *''49win (GIGA)'' *''Agenda'' *''[[NBC|Best Of The Ticket NBC]]'' *''[[Blue Night (television program)|Blue Night]]'' *''[[Bonanza]]'' *''[[CNBC|Business Insiders]]'' *''[[CNBC|Business Tonight]]'' *''[[CNBC|Business Weekly]]'' *''[[CNBC Asia|Chinese News Europe]]'' *''[[CNBC Europe|CNBC Business Weekly]]'' *''[[Squawk Box Europe|CNBC European Squawk Box]]'' *''[[Squawk Box|CNBC U. S. Squawk Box]]'' *''[[Dateline NBC|Dateline NBC With Jane Pauley And Stone Phillips]]'' *''Daybreak'' *''[[The Detectives]]'' *''Disaster Chronicles'' *''Eco Record'' *''Equal Time'' *''[[British Sky Broadcasting|European Business Today]]'' *''Film Europe'' *''[[Financial Times|FT Business Today]]'' *''[[Financial Times|FT Business Tonight]]'' *''[[Financial Times|FT European Business Today]]'' *''GIGA green'' (later: ''GIGA@ the gate'') *''GIGA Games'' *''GIGA Heartbeat'' *''Holidays'' *''Hotline'' *''[[Inside Edition]]'' *''[[ITN World News|ITN Super Channel News]]'' *''[[ITN World News]]'' *''Kinowelt-De News'' *''[[Late Night with Conan O'Brien]]'' *''[[NBC|Later]]'' *''Max's European Home Video Show'' *''Media Television'' *''The Mix'' *''[[The Money Wheel|Money Wheel]]'' {{col-2}} *''[[CNBC Europe|European Money Wheel]]'' *''[[The Money Wheel|U. Money Wheel]]'' *''[[Mr. Rhodes]]'' *''[[MSNBC|MSNBC - The Site]]'' *''[[MSNBC|MSNBC Internight Live]]'' *''[[National Geographic Channel|National Geographic]]'' *''NBC GIGA'' *''NBC GIGA Real'' *''[[NBC News|NBC News Special Reports]]'' *''[[Today (NBC program)|NBC News Today]]'' *''[[NBC Nightly News|NBC Nightly News With Tom Brokaw]]'' *''[[NBC Sports|NBC Sports News]]'' *''[[NHL on NBC|NHL International Weekly]]'' *''[[NBC|On The Air]]'' *''[[NBC|Personal]]'' *''[[The Pretender (TV series)|The Pretender]]'' *''[[Profiler (TV series)|Profiler]]'' *''Real Personal'' *''[[List of soap operas|Riviera]]'' *''[[Rolonda Watts|The Rolonda Watts Show]]'' *''[[Saturday Night Live]]'' *''[[Selina Scott|The Selina Scott Show]]'' *''Super Channel Documentaries'' *''Super Channel Sports Specials'' *''SMS Challenge (GIGA)'' *''[[ShopNBC|Super Shop]]'' *''Talkin' Jazz'' *''[[Time and Again (TV series)|Time and Again]]'' *''[[The Today Show]]'' *''[[Today's Business]]'' *''[[The Tonight Show with Jay Leno]]'' *''Travel Express'' *''[[CNBC|U. S. Market Wrap Up]]'' *''[[PGA Tour]]'' *''[[Union Square (TV series)|Union Square]]'' *''Victory'' *''West Of Moscow'' *''Young Soul Rebels'' {{col-end}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20051028125500/http://www.iht.com/articles/1994/03/16/nbc.php Uphill Struggle for Pan-Europe Stations : Televising to a Continent] article from ''[[International Herald Tribune]]'' March 16, 1994 *{{webarchive |url=https://archive.is/20121224080905/http://www2.tv-ark.org.uk/otherchannels/superchannel.html |date=24 December 2012 |title=Superchannel at TV Ark}} {{Original UK satellite channels}} {{Television in the Netherlands}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Nbc Europe}} [[Category:Satellite television]] [[Category:Defunct British television channels]] [[Category:Defunct German television channels]] [[Category:National Broadcasting Company]] [[Category:Television channels and stations established in 1987]] [[Category:Television channels and stations disestablished in 1998]] [[Category:Television channels and stations disestablished in 2005]] [[Category:Defunct television channels in the Netherlands]] [[Category:2005 disestablishments in Germany]]

{{Infobox newspaper | name = Point24 | logo = | image = | caption = | type = [[Free daily newspaper]] | format = [[Compact (newspaper)|Compact]] | owners = [[Saint-Paul Luxembourg]] | founder = | publisher = [[Saint-Paul Luxembourg]] | editor = | chiefeditor = | assoceditor = | maneditor = | newseditor = | managingeditordesign = | campuseditor = | campuschief = | opeditor = | sportseditor = | photoeditor = | staff = | foundation = 27 November 2007 | political = | language = [[French language|French]], [[German language|German]] and [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]] | ceased publication = | headquarters = 2 rue Christophe Plantin,
L-2988 [[Luxembourg (city)|Luxembourg City]] | circulation = | sister newspapers = | ISSN = | oclc = | website = [http://www.point24.lu/ www.point24.lu] }} '''''Point24''''' is a [[free daily newspaper]] in [[Luxembourg]]. ==History and profile== ''Point24'' was established in 2007.{{cite web|title=Media|url=http://vienne.mae.lu/en/Information-about-Luxembourg/Media|work=Embassy of Luxembourg in Vienna|accessdate=2 February 2014}} It is published by [[Saint-Paul Luxembourg]]. Originally published exclusively in [[French language|French]], like the rival freesheet ''[[L'essentiel]]'', ''Point24'' then was divided, with a [[German language|German]] front page and a French one, opposite to each other. Later on the 2 versions were divided into 2 separate newspapers, in a smaller format, magazine like. Finally in February 2011 a Portuguese version of the newspaper, with editions on Thursdays and Tuesdays, was launched. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{fr icon}} [https://web.archive.org/web/20071011014952/http://point24.lu/ Point24 official website] {{Newspapers in Luxembourg}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Point24}} [[Category:Daily newspapers published in Luxembourg]] [[Category:Publications established in 2007]] [[Category:French-language newspapers published in Luxembourg]] [[Category:German-language newspapers published in Luxembourg]] [[Category:2007 establishments in Luxembourg]] [[Category:Free daily newspapers]] [[Category:Portuguese-language newspapers]] {{Luxembourg-newspaper-stub}}

{{Infobox Network | name = Rai Internazionale Radio | logo = [[File:Rai Italia - Logo 2017.svg|150px]] | country = [[Italy]] | network_type = [[Radio network]] | available = International | owner = [[RAI]] through Rai Internazionale | key_people = ''Maurizio Imbriale'' (Head of the Rai International Internet project) | launch_date = July 1, 1930 | dissolved = December 31, 2011 | past_names = | website = [http://www.internazionale.rai.it/engl/] |}}
'''Rai Internazionale Radio''', formerly known as ''Rai Italia Radio'', ''Rai International Radio'', ''Rai Satelradio'' and ''Raitalia Radio'', was the official [[international broadcast]] radio service of Rai Internazionale, a subsidiary owned by [[RAI]], Italy's public broadcaster.
==History== Rai Internazionale Radio has been broadcasting from [[Rome]] to the rest of the world for the past 72 years under various names.
In the 1930s Italy was one of the first countries to begin international [[shortwave]] broadcasts. [[Guglielmo Marconi]], the man who invented radio, oversaw the construction of the first short-wave transmitter at Prato Smeraldo outside Rome on July 1, 1930. Four years later two more transmitters were completed and broadcasts began in [[English language|English]] and [[Italian language|Italian]] to North America. In 1935 broadcasting of programmes in [[Italian language|Italian]], [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]] and [[Spanish language|Spanish]] began to South America.
In 1939, after the completion of six new transmitters, programmes in [[English language|English]] were beamed to the Far East, Europe and countries around the Mediterranean. It is from the short-wave radio centre at Rome-Prato Smeraldo that all Rai International's programmes are broadcast.
During the Second World War political and strategic motives were added to the original aim of linking Italy with the vast community of Italian migrants around the world. These new motives included international broadcasting common to all the Great Powers, beginning with the former colonial nations: [[France]], [[Germany]], [[Great Britain]], the [[Netherlands]], the [[Soviet Union]] and the [[United States]]. After Italy entered the war short-wave broadcasts were suspended following the armistice signed with the Allies on September 8, 1943, and were only resumed on September 3, 1946, with the broadcast of news bulletins in [[English language|English]], [[Italian language|Italian]], [[French language|French]], [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]] and [[Spanish language|Spanish]].
A 1962 law allocated management of international short-wave broadcasts, for which a special committee of the Cabinet Office is responsible, to state broadcaster Rai. As the years went by the programmes lost their character of official - sometimes even propaganda - broadcasts to become a news source that fully reflects the democratic nature of the Italian Republic. Up to the last broadcast, Radio Roma offered a comprehensive news service on Italian politics, society and culture, not least within the context of the European Union.
In 1975 the setting up of a special management section for foreign broadcasting and journalism laid the foundations for significant development of the sector. Subsequently the existing services for foreign broadcasting were expanded to include Rai International's new intercontinental television channels. In the near future Rai International is destined to be transformed into an autonomous company within state broadcaster Rai.
==Last broadcasts== Each day Rai Internazionale's editorial team turned out ten editions of "''Italia chiama Italia News''" in [[Italian language|Italian]]: this 25-minute news programme was designed for Italian listeners throughout the world.
The editorial team also produced ''Racconto Italiano'', ''Taccuino Italiano'', ''Tutto di Prima'' and ''Storia e Storie''.
In many countries it was possible to receive several Rai Internazionale programmes or the entire programme schedule of Rai Internazionale through local radio stations that re-transmit the signal in their own zone, on AM, FM, short wave or via cable.
On October 1, 2007, all broadcasts on short wave were discontinued and foreign language services were closed. On December 31, 2011 Rai Internazionale Radio closed down its operations.
English news items were transmitted as part of "Notturno Italiano" programme on medium wave until December 31, 2011.
==Rai Internazionale Radio== Rai Internazionale Radio transmitted its channel online and on satellite, 24 hours a day. Thus the radio and news programmes produced by RAI were available worldwide without any special technical devices (apart from a computer and Internet connection).
Rai Internazionale Radio has broadcast the best of Rai International Radio and the three Radio Rai networks daily, 24 hours a day. This included music, information and entertainment programmes until it closed down on December 31, 2011.
== See also == * [[RAI|Rai]], Italy's publicly funded national broadcaster * [[Rai Italia]], international television service run by Italy's national broadcaster
==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20111126052916/http://www.internazionale.rai.it/engl/ Rai Internazionale Radio Website] {{en icon}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20111127110344/http://www.internazionale.rai.it/raitalia.tv/radio_live.php Live Streaming] * [http://portale.italradio.org/index.php?name=News&file=article&sid=2305 information about the closing down]
{{RAI}}
[[Category:RAI radio stations]] [[Category:External services (broadcasting)]] [[Category:Radio stations established in 1930]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox diocese |jurisdiction = Diocese |name = Sisak |latin = Dioecesis Sisciensis |local = Sisačka biskupija |country = {{flag|Croatia}} |metropolitan = [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Zagreb|Zagreb]] |rite = [[Latin Rite]] |cathedral = [[Sisak Cathedral]] |cocathedral = |area_km2 = 5500 |population = 198,156 |population_as_of = 2014 |catholics = 163,844 |catholics_percent= 82.7 |pope = {{Incumbent pope}} |bishop = [[Vlado Košić]] |metro_archbishop = [[Josip Bozanić]] |coadjutor = |auxiliary_bishops= }} The [[Roman Catholic]] '''Diocese of Sisak''' ({{lang-hr|Sisačka biskupija}}; {{lang-la|Dioecesis Sisciensis}}) is a [[Latin rite]] [[suffragan diocese]] in the [[Ecclesiastical province]] of the Metropolitan of [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Zagreb|Zagreb]], in [[Sisak-Moslavina]] region, [[Croatia]]. Its [[cathedral]] episcopal see is Katedrala Uzvišenja sv. Križa, dedicated to [[Exaltation of the Holy Cross]], in the city of [[Sisak]],
which also has a [[Minor basilica]]: Bazilika Sv. Kvirina, dedicated to Saint martyr [[Quirinus of Sescia]] (the first bishop). ==History== * Established in the 3rd century as '''Diocese of [[Siscia]]''' (the Roman Sisak). Although Siscia became the capital of the [[Roman province]] of [[Pannonia Savia]] (the southwestern quarter of Pannonia), it was not raised to Metropolitan status. Its history remains sketchy. * By the 7th century it may already have become extinct, its territory being taken over by the then [[Roman Catholic Diocese of Zagreb|Diocese of Zagreb]], its future Metropolitan (promoted 1852) around the 10th century, the Sisak see being formally suppressed no later than the 11th century. * In May 1999, the diocese was nominally restored as Latin Episcopal [[titular bishopric]] of Sisak (Curiate Italian) / Siscia (Latin) / 錫薩克 (正體中文) / Siscien(sis) (Latin adjective), but would only have a single incumbent, of the higher archiepiscopal rank. * On 5 December 2009 [[Pope Benedict XVI]] re-erected the residential '''Diocese of Sisak''', resurrecting the titular title and splitting (back) off its present territory from its Metropolitan, the [[Archdiocese of Zagreb]], an unusual instance of a titular diocese of the Catholic Church becoming a residential one again. On the same day the Pope erected the new [[Diocese of Bjelovar-Križevci]], also within the Ecclesiastical province of Zagreb in Croatia. == Statistics == As per 2014, it pastorally served 163,844 Catholics (82.7% of 198,156 total) on 5,500 km² in 77 parishes with 63 priests (43 diocesan, 20 religious), 102 lay religious (20 brothers, 82 sisters) and 8 seminarians. ==Episcopal ordinaries== (all [[Roman rite]]) ;''Suffragan Bishops of Ancient Siscia / Sisak * Saint martyr [[Quirinus of Sescia]] : ''next centuries incomplete * Marcus (mentioned in 343) * Constantius I (in 381) * ... * Johannes (in 530) * Constantius II (in 532) * Vindemius (before 579 - after 590) Other authors assign him to the Istrian diocese of [[Cissa (titular see)|Cissa]] (now Novalja and a titular bishopric) * ... ;''Titular Bishop of Sisak * ''Titular Archbishop [personal rank]: Nikola Eterović (born Croatia) (1999.05.22 – 2009.11.25) as papal diplomat and [[Roman Curia]] official : [[Apostolic Nuncio]] (papal ambassador) to [[Ukraine]] (1999.05.22 – 2004.02.11), Secretary General of [[General Synod of Bishops]] (2004.02.11 – 2013.09.21); 'transferred' (as the title of Sisak was no longer available as titular see) Titular Archbishop of [[Vinkovci]] (2009.11.25 – ...) and next Apostolic Nuncio to Germany (2013.09.21 – ...). ;''Suffragan Bishops of Sisak (modern bishopric) * Vlado Košić (2009.12.05 - ...), previously [[Titular Bishop]] of [[Ruspæ]] (1998.12.29 – 2009.12.05) as [[Auxiliary Bishop]] of [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Zagreb|Archdiocese of Zagreb]] (Croatia) (1998.12.29 – 2009.12.05). == See also == * [[List of Catholic dioceses in Croatia]] * [[Roman Catholicism in Croatia]] * [[Sisak-Moslavina County]] == Notes == {{Reflist}} == Sources and external links == * [http://www.gcatholic.org/dioceses/diocese/sisa0.htm GCatholic, with Google map & satellite photo - data for all sections] * [http://www.biskupija-sisak.hr Official site of Roman Catholic Diocese of Sisak (in Croatian)] * [http://www.catholic-hierarchy.org/diocese/dsisa.html Catholic Hierarchy] * [[:it:Diocesi di Sisak|Italian Wikipedia]] * [http://212.77.1.245/news_services/bulletin/news/24768.php?index=24768&po_date=05.12.2009&lang=en From the Vatican Press Office]{{dead link|date=April 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} * [http://www.cattoliciromani.com/forum/showthread.php/le_nomine_benedetto_xvi-22397p174.html Cattolici Romani site (in Italian)] ; Bibliography * Bolla Antiquam fidem, vatican.va. * Jacques Zeiller, ''Les origines chrétiennes dans les provinces danubiennes de l'empire romain'', Paris 1918, pp. 139–140 {{coord|45.4843|N|16.3725|E|source:wikidata|display=title}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Sisak, Roman Catholic Diocese}} [[Category:Roman Catholic dioceses in Croatia]] [[Category:Catholic titular sees in Europe]] [[Category:Former Roman Catholic dioceses in Croatia]] [[Category:Suppressed Roman Catholic dioceses]] [[Category:Dioceses established in the 3rd century|Dioceses established in the 3rd century]] {{Europe-RC-diocese-stub}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2014}} {{Infobox company | name = Shelter Afrique | logo = | type = [[Private company|Private]] | owner = 44 African Governments
[[AfDB]]
'''Africa Re''' | slogan = | foundation = 1982 | location = Longonot Road, [[Upper Hill, Nairobi|Upper Hill]]
[[Nairobi]], [[Kenya]] | key_people = '''Corneille Karekezi'''
[[Chairman]]
'''James Mugerwa'''
[[Managing Director]] & [[CEO]]{{cite web|url=http://www.businessdailyafrica.com/Corporate-News/Shelter-Afrique-picks-Ugandan-as-new-MD-/-/539550/2360598/-/fftp7rz/-/index.html|accessdate=26 June 2014|date=24 June 2014| first=Mugambi|last=Mutegi|publisher=[[Nation Media Group|Business Africa Daily]]|title=Shelter Afrique Picks Ugandan As New MD}} | num_employees = | industry = [[Finance]] | products =[[Finance|Project finance]], [[Lending|Institutional lending]], [[Investment|Equity investments]], [[Trade|Trade finance]] & [[Housing|Social housing]] | assets =US$270,189,481 (2013) | revenue ={{profit}}US$ 4.75 million (2013) | homepage = [http://www.shelterafrique.org/ Homepage] }} '''Shelter Afrique''' '''(SAf)''', also known as '''Company for Habitat and Housing in Africa''', is a pan-African finance institution created to exclusively support the development of the African real estate and housing sector. Through its strategic partnerships, it offers products and related services which support the efficient delivery of commercial real estate and affordable housing. ==Location== The main offices of the organization are located in a building on Longonot Road, [[Upper Hill, Nairobi|Upper Hill]], in [[Nairobi]], the [[capital city|capital]] of [[Kenya]]. A regional office is located at 1129, Muhktar El-Yakub’s Place, Central Business District, [[Abuja]], [[Nigeria]]'s capital city. ==Overview== {{asof|December 2017}}, SAf was a large multinational organization with total assets valued at approximately US$312 million, and shareholders' equity of about US$131 million.{{cite web|url=http://www.shelterafrique.org/wp-content/uploads/2018/06/ShAf-2017-Annual-Report-Final-English-1.pdf|title=Shelter Afrique 2017 Annual Report & Accounts|last=SAf|first=.|date=31 December 2017|website=http://www.shelterafrique.org/|publisher=Shelter Afrique (SAf)|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=4 September 2018}} Besides using its own funds, SAf has a list of collaborating financial institutions which provide funding for onward lending in the real estate and housing arena within the continent. Partner funding sources include: (a) [[Netherlands Development Finance Company]] (b) [[French Development Agency]] (c) [[European Investment Bank]] and (d) [[Commercial Bank of Africa]].{{cite web| publisher=[[The Standard (Kenya)]]|last=Anyanzwa|date=22 June 2014| url=http://www.standardmedia.co.ke/business/article/2000125705/shelter-afrique-secures-sh1-7b-housing-projects-in-africa?pageNo=1|title=Shelter Afrique Secures KSh1.7 Billion Housing Projects In Africa|first=James|accessdate=26 June 2014}} SAf also works in collaboration with several international organizations with similar objectives, namely: 1. International Union of Housing Finance (IUHF) 2. Centre for Affordable Housing Finance in Africa (CAHF) and 3. UN Habitat for A Better Urban Future (UN-Habitat).{{cite web| url=http://www.shelterafrique.org/index.php/about-us/our-history-partners-and-shareholders/ |title=Shelter Afrique: History & Partners|first=.|last=SAf|publisher=Shelter Afrique (SAf)|date=2013|accessdate=26 June 2014}} ==Shareholders== The organization has 44 member African countries and two African financial multinational institutions:{{cite web| url=http://www.shelterafrique.org/index.php/shelter-afrique-2013-annual-report-accounts/|title=Detailed Shareholding In Shelter Afrique (Part of 2013 Financial Report)|date=15 March 2014|first=.| last=SAf|publisher=Shelter Afrique (SAf)|accessdate=26 June 2014}} {{columns-list|colwidth=18em| * [[AfDB]] * African Re * [[Algeria]] * [[Benin]] * [[Botswana]] * [[Burkina-Faso]] * [[Burundi]] * [[Cameroon]] * [[Cape Verde]] * [[Central African Republic|CAR]] * [[Chad]] * [[Republic of the Congo|Congo]] * [[Djibouti]] * [[Democratic Republic of the Congo|DRC]] * [[Equatorial Guinea|EQ Guinea]] * [[Gabon]] * [[Gambia]] * [[Ghana]] * [[Guinea]] * [[Guinea-Bissau]] * [[Ivory Coast]] * [[Kenya]] * [[Liberia]] * [[Lesotho]] * [[Madagascar]] * [[Malawi]] * [[Mali]] * [[Mauritania]] * [[Mauritius]] * [[Morocco]] * [[Namibia]] * [[Niger]] * [[Nigeria]] * [[Rwanda]] * [[Sao Tome and Principe|Sao Tome]] * [[Senegal]] * [[Seychelles]] * [[Sierra Leone]] * [[Somalia]] * [[Swaziland]] * [[Tanzania]] * [[Togo]] * [[Tunisia]] * [[Uganda]] * [[Zambia]] * [[Zimbabwe]] }} ==Governance== '''Nghidinua Daniel''', a national of [[Namibia]], serves as the Chairman of the Board of Directors. The Managing Director is '''Femi Adewole''' a national of [[Nigeria]].{{cite web|url=http://www.shelterafrique.org/wp-content/uploads/2018/06/ShAf-2017-Annual-Report-Final-English-1.pdf|title=Shelter Afrique 2017 Annual Report|last=Shelter Afrique|first=|date=31 December 2017|website=www.shelterafrique.org/|publisher=Shelter Afrique|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=4 September 2018}} ==See also== * [[Common Market for Eastern and Southern Africa]] * [[PTA Bank]] * [[African Development Bank]] * [[East African Development Bank]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.businessdailyafrica.com/Shelter-Afrique-in-Sh790m-deal-with-UG-firm/-/539552/2392170/-/wlfksbz/-/index.html Shelter Afrique In KSh790 Million (US$9 Million) Deal With Uganda Firm] *[http://businessdayonline.com/2014/06/shelter-afrique-fg-to-deliver-10000-affordable-houses-in-six-months-afolayan/#.U6yXT2zD-LA Shelter Afrique, FG to deliver 10,000 affordable houses in six months – Afolayan] *[http://www.businessdailyafrica.com/Shelter-Afrique-eyes-Nigerian-market/-/539552/2873650/-/wgrmq8z/-/index.html Shelter Afrique Eyes Nigerian Market to Raise Cash for Lending] {{DEFAULTSORT:Shelter Afrique}} [[Category:International organizations of Africa]] [[Category:International development in Africa]] [[Category:Economy of Africa]] [[Category:Multilateral development banks]] [[Category:Development finance institutions]] [[Category:Real estate in Africa]]

{{Multiple issues| {{citation style|date=August 2017}} {{refimprove|date=August 2017}} }} {{Infobox institute |name = Cultural and Informational Institute of Tabiban
مؤسسه فرهنگی و اطلاع‌رسانی تبیان |image = | image_size = |caption = |commercial? = yes |type = [[cultural]] and [[educational]] |established = 2002 |place = [[Tehran]] }} '''Tebyan Cultural Institute''' is a [[cultural]] and [[educational]] [[organization]].[http://www.alexa.com/siteinfo/tebyan.net tebyan.net Traffic Statistics] [http://www.isna.ir/news/96012007554/%D8%B1%D8%A7%D9%87-%D8%A7%D9%86%D8%AF%D8%A7%D8%B2%DB%8C-%D8%B7%D8%B1%D8%AD-%D9%87%D9%85%D8%B3%D8%A7%D9%86-%DA%AF%D8%B2%DB%8C%D9%86%DB%8C-%D8%AF%D8%B1-%DA%86%D9%87%D8%A7%D8%B1%D9%85%DB%8C%D9%86-%D8%A7%D8%B3%D8%AA%D8%A7%D9%86-%DA%A9%D8%B4%D9%88%D8%B1 About Tebyan on the Islamic Republic News Agency website, 2017][http://article.tebyan.net/296553/%D9%87%D8%A7%D8%B3%D8%AA-%D8%B1%D8%A7%DB%8C%DA%AF%D8%A7%D9%86-%D8%A8%D8%B1%D8%A7%DB%8C-%DA%A9%D8%A7%D8%B1%D8%A8%D8%B1%D8%A7%D9%86-%D8%AA%D8%A8%DB%8C%D8%A7%D9%86Official About the Tebyan cultural institute] == History == The Tebyan Cultural Institute was founded in 2002 in [[Iran]]. Its [[Alexa internet]] ranking is 15 in Iran.[http://www.alexa.com/siteinfo/tebyan.net tebyan.net Traffic Statistics] == Activities == * Publication of [[cultural]] information on the [[World Wide Web|web]] * Supporting cultural products in [[information technology]] * Publication of free of charge information on Tebyan's [[website]] * Providing consultation in [[religious]] issues The Tebyan cultural institute, which is affiliated to the organization "Sazman-e Tablighat-e Eslami",[https://books.google.ca/books?id=e8CYMpJUxbcC&pg=PA263&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=tebyan&f=false ''Gaming Globally: Production, Play, and Place'', edited by N. Huntemann, B. Aslinger, p. 263, Nina B. Huntemann and Ben Aslinger, 2013] is one of the biggest and best known cultural institutes in Iran, and has cooperated with other cultural institutes in different fields for supporting cultural [[festival]]s and broadcasting their activities in the [[Media (communication)|media]].[http://ido.ir/en/news/?id=831 The Islamic Development Organization website, 2017] The activities of the institute’s takep lace not only in [[Tehran]], but also in the provincial centers, and 1,600,000 users visit its website each day.[http://old.ido.ir/en/en-n.aspx?n=13891028077 The Islamic Development Organization website, visited in 2017] The Iranian deputy minister supported its activities for sport and youth on the website tebyan.net in Tehran.[http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-3128483/Ministry-matchmaking-Iran-launches-state-sponsored-website-help-11million-singletons-married-solve-country-s-family-crisis.html About tebyan on Dailymail][http://www.abc.net.au/news/2015-06-16/with-marriage-out-of-favour-iran-turns-to-matchmaking/6548292 About tebyan on the ABC news website] The new site of the Tebyan Cultural Institute is called hamsan.tebyan.net and is run by the Islamic Development Organisation.[https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-32833363 About tebyan on the BBC website] == Notes == {{Reflist|30em}} == [http://www.abc.net.au/news/2015-06-16/with-marriage-out-of-favour-iran-turns-to-matchmaking/6548292 About tebyan on the ABC news website] * Dailymail] * [http://www.ibna.ir/en/doc/naghli/212841/tebyan-institute-introduces-digital-library-at-20th-elecomp About tebyan on the Iran Book News Agency website] * About the Tebyan cultural institute] * revision.text:
{{Infobox spaceflight | name = USA-50 | image = | image_caption = | insignia = | mission_type = [[Navigation satellite|Navigation]] | operator = [[US Air Force]] | COSPAR_ID = 1990-008A | SATCAT = 20452 | mission_duration = 7.5 years (planned) | spacecraft = | spacecraft_type = [[GPS Block II]] | manufacturer = [[Rockwell International|Rockwell]] | launch_mass = {{convert|840|kg}} | dimensions = | power = | launch_date = {{start-date|24 January 1990, 22:55:01|timezone=yes}} UTC | launch_rocket = {{nowrap|[[Delta II|Delta II 6925]],}} D191 | launch_site = [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station|Cape Canaveral]] [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station Space Launch Complex 17|LC-17A]] | entered_service = | disposal_type = | deactivated = {{end-date|18 August 2000}} | orbit_epoch = | orbit_reference = [[geocentric orbit|Geocentric]] | orbit_regime = [[Medium Earth orbit|Medium Earth]]
([[Semi-synchronous orbit|Semi-synchronous]]) | orbit_periapsis = {{convert|20087|km}} | orbit_apoapsis = {{convert|20275|km}} | orbit_inclination = 54.6 degrees | orbit_period = 717.92 minutes | apsis = gee }} '''USA-50''', also known as '''GPS II-6''' and '''GPS SVN-18''', was an [[United States|American]] [[navigation satellite]] which formed part of the [[Global Positioning System]]. It was the sixth of nine [[GPS Block II|Block II]] GPS satellites to be launched, which were the first operational GPS satellites to fly. USA-50 was launched at 22:55:01 UTC on 24 January 1990, atop a [[Delta II]] carrier rocket, flight number D191, flying in the 6925 configuration.{{cite web|url=http://planet4589.org/space/log/launchlog.txt|title=Launch Log|publisher=Jonathan's Space Page|first=Jonathan|last=McDowell|accessdate=10 July 2012}} The launch took place from [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station Space Launch Complex 17|Launch Complex 17A]] at the [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station]],{{cite web|url=http://planet4589.org/space/lvdb/list2.html|title=Launch List|publisher=Jonathan's Space Page|work=Launch Vehicle Database|first=Jonathan|last=McDowell|accessdate=10 July 2012}} and placed USA-50 into a transfer orbit. The satellite raised itself into [[medium Earth orbit]] using a [[Star-37XFP]] [[apogee motor]].{{cite web|url=http://space.skyrocket.de/doc_sdat/navstar-2.htm|title=GPS-2 (Navstar-2)|first=Gunter|last=Krebs|work=Gunter's Space Page|accessdate=10 July 2012}} On 25 February 1990, USA-50 was in an orbit with a [[apsis|perigee]] of {{convert|20087|km}}, an [[apsis|apogee]] of {{convert|20275|km}}, a [[orbital period|period]] of 717.92 minutes, and 54.6 degrees of [[inclination]] to the equator.{{cite web|url=http://planet4589.org/space/log/satcat.txt|title=Satellite Catalog|publisher=Jonathan's Space Page|first=Jonathan|last=McDowell|accessdate=10 July 2012}} The satellite had a mass of {{convert|840|kg}}, and generated 710 watts of power.{{cite web|url=http://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/nmc/spacecraftDisplay.do?id=1990-008A|title=Navstar 2-06|publisher=US National Space Science Data Center|accessdate=10 July 2012}} It had a design life of 7.5 years, and was retired from service on 18 August 2000. ==References== {{reflist}} {{Portal|Spaceflight}} {{GPS satellites}} {{Orbital launches in 1990}} [[Category:GPS satellites]] [[Category:USA satellites]] [[Category:Spacecraft launched in 1990]] {{US-spacecraft-stub}}
